Good day, everyone. Welcome to the Xcel Energy Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Call. Today's call is being recorded.
At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Paul Johnson, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In add
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition, we have other members of management team in the room to answer questions if necessary.
This morning, we will review our 2014 full year results, reaffirm our 2015 earnings guidance range, and update you on strategic plans and business -- that related to business and regulatory developments. Slides that accompany today's call are available on our web page. In addition, we will posted a brief video on our website of Teresa summarizing our financial later this morning.
As a reminder, some of the comments during today's conference call may contain forward-looking information. Significant factors that could cause results to differ from those anticipated are described in our earnings release and our filings with the SEC.
I'll now turn the call over to Ben.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good morning. I'm going to start by highlighting some of the key successes of 2014. And update you on some exciting developments that Xcel. Teresa will provide more detail on some of these items.2014 was another strong year for Xcel
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good morning. I'm going to start by highlighting some of the key successes of 2014. And update you on some exciting developments that Xcel. Teresa will provide more detail on some of these items.
2014 was another strong year for Xcel Energy, as the company recorded earnings of $2.03 per share. This marks the 10th consecutive year we've met or exceeded our earnings guidance. And is fifth consecutive year we've delivered earnings in the upper half of our guidance range.  In addition, we raised our dividend for the 11th year on a row.
From a regulatory perspective, we made significant progress up rate cases at Wisconsin, New Mexico and Texas. We received a constructive ALJ recommendation in Minnesota. And most recently, reached a favorable 3-year settlement in our Colorado electric case. When we filed the case in Colorado, we stated that our objective was to establish a multiyear regulatory plan that provides certainty for and its customers. This settlement accomplishes that goal, and provides us a reasonable opportunity to earn our authorized return in our Colorado elected business over the next 3 years.
From an operational perspective, I also wanted to take a moment to say how incredibly proud I am of the efforts of our employees this year. We have record levels of safety in 2014, improving for the seventh straight year. And again, we demonstrated our top-tier operating performance with industry-leading reliabilities scores.
Recall last quarter, we unveiled our refresh strategic plan that was focused on improving utility performance, including the goal of closing the ROE gap by 50 basis points, and increasing the amount of revenue generated from long-term regulatory agreement.  Driving operational excellence by focusing on limiting annual increases and O&M cost of between 0% and 2%. Providing our customers more options and solutions, and finally, investing for the future by focusing on incremental growth opportunities in our natural gas and transmission businesses.
Today, we're excited to update you on our progress we've made on some of these initiatives. The electric utility industry is in the midst of a major transition, and we're committed to being on the front end of this change. We will be a leader in the same way we proactively implemented our environmental strategy over a decade ago.
To this end, we are pursuing regulatory changes to better align with the clear direction that customer preferences, federal policies and state initiatives are moving. Last one, in Minnesota, a collaborative report was issued by a diverse stakeholder group known as the E21 initiative. The group released a set of recommendations that are to act as a blueprint for a new customer centric performance based regulatory approach.
Following E21 report, we filed with the Minnesota Commission, a framework on how we envision enabling these changes. We focused on 4 key objectives. Lowering carbon emission by 40% by 2030; pioneer in distribution grid monetization; responding to changing customer preferences and providing new services and products. And finally, pursuing more predictable and nimble rate recovery.
In order to effectively bring about these changes, it is essential to the company have a longer-term more holistic regulatory compact. Longer term multiyear agreements and additional writers are expected to improve visibility and supplement our efforts. Further, the company has tools that the unutilized stabilize rate increases and make more printable for our customers. We expect to work with the commission and various stakeholders in Minnesota in 2015. We've developed this new framework and have requested a planning meeting in the coming months to discuss options in greater detail.
We're also exploring ways for us to avoid the need to file a 2016 rate case, which will allow more time to concentrate on the longer-term regulatory framework.
In January, we filed our resource plan in Minnesota, which provides details on how we will achieve our commitment to reduce carbon emissions by 40% by 2030. This will be accomplished by significantly increasing the amount of solar and wind on the NSP system. Adding natural gas generation, continuing our industry-leading commitment to conservation programs, operating our nuclear plants at least through their current licenses, and continue to run units 1 and 2 with gradual decrease reliance from those units through 2030.
This proactive, no regrets strategy will better position the company and our customers for the long run, and do so at an incremental cost of less than 3% through 2030. As a result, by 2030, 63% of our energy will be carbon free at NSP. Clearly, 2015 is going to be a transformational year in Minnesota.
While much of our discussion is focused on Minnesota, we are also pursuing changes in our Texas jurisdiction. Along with other non- utilities, we will be sponsoring legislation this session that will help reduce regulatory lag, and allow us to continue to invest in the systems to support growth in the region, which is continuing even in the phase of a challenging oil price environment.
Finally, we wanted to update you on our natural gas growth initiatives. As we mentioned last quarter, we plan to file a general rate case for our Colorado gas business. Finally will include a number of investments to maintain and improve the safety and reliability of our natural gas infrastructure.
Concurrent with our rate case, we will begin working with our commission and major stakeholders to explore rate basing natural gas reserves, as a weighted took advantage of the current low natural gas price and to provide a longer-term hedge for our customers. Following our stakeholders and outreach and education, we expect to make a separate filing to begin the regulatory process. We're excited by the progress we've made in the steps we've taken thus far. And I look forward to updating you later this year.
So with that I'll turn the call over to Theresa.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, I'll be focusing my discussion on full-year 2014 results. We are pleased to close out another solid year with ongoing earnings of $2.03 per share compared with 2013 ongoing earnings of $1.95 per share.The most signi
componenttext:
Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, I'll be focusing my discussion on full-year 2014 results. We are pleased to close out another solid year with ongoing earnings of $2.03 per share compared with 2013 ongoing earnings of $1.95 per share.
The most significant driver us to 2014 earnings was improved electric and natural gas margins that benefited from new rates and increased rider revenues in many of our jurisdictions. Increased margin more than offset and unfavorable weather comparison and higher O&M depreciation and property taxes. It is worth noting that the weather in 2014 contributed $0.03 per share when compared to normal. In contrast, in 2013, weather contributed $0.11 per share, resulting in a $0.08 per share decline when comparing the 2 years.
Now let me provide an update on sales and the economies in our local service territories.
We experienced positive growth trends in 2014 with weather normalized retail electric sales increasing 1.3% and firm natural gas sales improving 4.6%. Sales in 2014 exceeded our original expectations for the year. While we are monitoring economic conditions in our service territories, and are closely watching potential implications from changes in the space, we remain confident in our 2015 electric weather adjusted sales growth assumption of 1%.
Let me provide a little more detail on sales growth by company. Beginning with NSP-Wisconsin, weather adjusted retail sales increased 3.3% in 2014, due to strengthen C&I sales from growth in the sand mining industry and related oil and gas businesses. Customer growth and modest usage increases drove higher residential sales. Electric sales at SPS increased to 2.3% driven by growth in the C&I
Oil and gas exploration in the Permian Basin continues to benefit the service territory. And we saw additional growth in uranium and Richmond. While we are watching oil price closely and expect some producers to reduce new drilling activity, we anticipate that others will continue to grow production.
PSCo sales increased 1.2%, which was primarily attributable to strengthen the C&I class due to new food manufacturing customers and energy sector growth. Finally, NSP-Minnesota sales increased 0.06% driven by growth in the number of residential and small C&I customers and usage increases in the small C&I class.
Economic conditions remained strong across Xcel Energy service territories relative to the nation as a whole. The consolidated unemployment rate in our regions of 3.6% remains well below the national average of 5.4%. In addition, the number of jobs in our regions grew 2.3% during 2014, compared with 1.9% for the nation.
Focusing more specifically on 2014 earnings, ongoing electric margin increased $215 million. Key drivers included, implementation of final and interim rates, which increased margin by $129 million; nonfuel riders increased margin by $57 million, increased transmission investments, which improved margin by $31 million; and retail sales growth excluding weather improved margins by $24 million. These positive impacts were partially offset by an unfavorable weather comparison year-over-year at $60 million, as well as a few other items.
The electric margin results reflect an estimated obligation for the Minnesota rate case, which is relatively consistent with the recent ALJ recommendation, and an estimated customer refund liability to capture the impact of our electric earnings test at PSCo.
Margins on the natural gas side of the business increased by $49 million for the year. This is primarily due to rate release in Colorado, significant infrastructure investment that is captured in an annual rider and retail sales growth.
O&M expenses increased $61 million or 2.7% for 2014. Solidly within our original guidance of 2% to 3% increase. The increase is primarily driven by higher, although, moderating nuclear costs. As we have discussed in the past, a key objective of our operational excellence strategic pillar is to limit O&M increases. We are reaffirming our 2015 O&M guidance of 0% to 2% consistent with our long-term objective.
In addition, I think it's worth mentioning that our 2015 O&M guidance assumption reflects a lower pension discount rate, and adoption of the recently updated mortality table.
Finally, other increased about $45 million or 11%, largely driven by higher property taxes in Minnesota, Texas and Colorado.
Next I'll update you on several regulatory proceedings. Additional details are included in our earnings release. In Colorado, we are pleased to have reached a settlement with parties that were successfully resolved our electric rate case. The agreement continues to productive multi-year regulatory compact that we've been operating under since 2012.  The settlement costs for a total increase of about $53 million or 1.9%, based on an ROE of 9.83%, and an equity ratio of 56%. In addition, we anticipate that PSCo will differ about the $3 million of expenses in 2015.
The agreement also stipulates that the clean air, clean jobs and transmission riders are forward-looking mechanisms.
It is worth noting then in our original Colorado rate case we had proposed shortening the depreciable life of certain assets, which would have led to a material increase in depreciation expense.  As a result of the settlement, PSCo will not be implementing the depreciation changes, and will avoid this incremental depreciation expense. Alternately, we agreed to file a standalone depreciation study early next year that will be Incorporated into our next rate care anticipated in 2018.
That commission is expected to rule out settlement in the first quarter, and rates are expected to be come effective in mid February.
Last month, we received the ALJ recommendation in our Minnesota electric case. We were encouraged by the -- that they judge acknowledged the strength of the company's position on many of the key issues, including pensions, benefits and depreciation.
When including the ALJ's recommended ROE of 9.77%, and adjusting for sales and property tax we estimate accumulative revenue increase of about $192 million for 2014 and 2015. Deliberations are currently scheduled from March.
Turning to our prudence review, we have not yet received the ALJ recommendation. We believe the delay is related to work load issues for the ALJ and anticipate the ALJ recommendation in February.
We continue to believe that we acted prudently in making decisions throughout the course of the project. In addition, the surrounding communities and our customers have a largely rebuild, safe and efficient source of carbon-free low-cost power for many years to come. Importantly, we don't believe that the delay in receiving the ALJ's recommendation will impact the current schedule, and we continue to expect the commission to on the proceeding in March.
In Texas, we filed a rate case requesting an increase in annual revenues of $65 million or 6.7%. Our filings reflects the inclusion of rate base additions, once of the items we're seeking legislative support for in Texas. New rates are expected to be implemented by mid-year. In South Dakota, we put interim rates for about $16 million in place on January 1, and continue to work through the regulatory process. Final rates are expected to be approved mid-year.
We also made progress on several other initiatives during the fourth quarter. In Wisconsin, the commission approved the settlement improvements, which we reached last year with staff and interveners for rate increase of $14 million or 2.2%. Rates went into effect earlier this month.
In Texas, the commission approved our settlement in the 2014 rate case, providing incremental revenue of $37 million or 3.5%. Rates went into effect retroactive to June 2014.
Finally, in Minnesota, the commission approved our gas infrastructure writer for $15 million with rates becoming effective in February 2015.
In summary, 2014 was a busy and productive year for us on the regulatory front. This morning, we are reaffirming our 2015 earnings guidance of $2 to $2.15 per share. Our guidance range is based on several key assumptions as described in our earnings release, including constructive outcomes in our regulatory proceedings. Please note that some of these assumptions have changed due primarily to incorporating actual 2014 results.
With that, I'll wrap up my comments. After a solid 2014, we're pleased to deliver earnings within our guidance range for the 10th consecutive year. We are reaffirming our 2015 earnings guidance range of $2 to $2.15 per share. Our 5-year capital plan of $14.5 billion, and our 4.7% rate base CAGR, even when considering the impacts from the recently passed depreciation legislation.
We continue to see improved economic conditions in our regions, and experienced better than expected sales growth. With 2014 weather adjusted retail electric sales growth of 1.3%, and weather adjusted firm natural gas sales growth of 4.6%. We are making meaningful progress on the regulatory front, including the recent multiyear settlement in Colorado, and expect to reach a conclusion in the Minnesota case in the next few months.
We delivered 2014 O&M expense growth within our guidance of 2% to 3% and continue to expect 2015 O&M to be flat to 2%.
And finally, we are well-positioned to deliver an attractive long-term value to our shareholders by growing earnings and our dividend 4% to 6%, annually.
So with that, operator, we'll now take questions.

componenttext: Sure. We're going to add, obviously, as part of that, the resource plan and tremendous amount of renewables, both wind and solar. A lot of it comes from in the 20 to 30 timeframe. I think that gives us a great opportunity to own a good piece of those investment opportunities for a couple of reasons: one, clearly, technology will come down, and it will most likely not have as much of the federal tax incentives that it does have now; two, our tax appetite should grow in coming years. So I think we should be well positioned to take advantage of some of those opportunities. Your second question was regarding ...

componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, there is a number of things that we want to do. I mean, increasingly customers want a different energy mix. They want a greener products. They want different billing options. It's basically just responding to the trend that we've seen that co
componenttext: Yes, I mean, there is a number of things that we want to do. I mean, increasingly customers want a different energy mix. They want a greener products. They want different billing options. It's basically just responding to the trend that we've seen that consumers one-size-fits-all, which has been a traditional utility needs the change. And we want to work with our commission and our staffs to make sure that we do that in a way that's fair to all. And be fixable enough to move forward with that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And just -- if you don't mind commenting on transmission here. I'd be curious where does your transco strategy stand, given some commentary from peers and the market overall of -- perhaps a lackluster spend trajectory here at least for 2015? Ho
componenttext: Excellent. And just -- if you don't mind commenting on transmission here. I'd be curious where does your transco strategy stand, given some commentary from peers and the market overall of -- perhaps a lackluster spend trajectory here at least for 2015? How does it drive with what your baking into expectations? And your own expectations for longer-term build-out of the transco? And perhaps the clarification on the last question, does that mean for solar? It's kind of an opportunity for you all post the 16 ITC, is that what I'm hearing from you?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It means that it would be -- that the opportunity improves significantly, doesn't mean we can't do something before that. But as you know, renewables are heavily driven by tax appetites, and you need one to efficiently, doesn't mean you're fully precluded
componenttext: It means that it would be -- that the opportunity improves significantly, doesn't mean we can't do something before that. But as you know, renewables are heavily driven by tax appetites, and you need one to efficiently, doesn't mean you're fully precluded. But to efficiently participate in those markets. Your question was about transcos and transmission. Well, keep in mind that, $4.5 billion of our CapEx over the next 5 years is in transmission. None of it is in the transco or -- and none of it assumes that we win any of the competitive transmission projects. So when you look that what's come out of and the ITP 10 plan? I think it was about $300-odd million of potential opportunities. By the way, it looks like a -- not an incident the amount of that would go into the -- to SPS. But we don't have -- that does not impact. That would be the icing on the cake. So our strategy is always been two-prong. We have the utility vehicle do invest in, that's where we are today. We're in the process of getting approval -- approvals, final approvals on our transco, so that we can participate in this competitive markets. I think we're well-positioned to do that. It's going a little bit slower as you mentioned than I think many people thought. It doesn't really surprise us. I think there'll be more opportunities in the years to come. And again, I think we'll be very well-positioned to win in those markets.

componenttext: Just historically, we've been running at about 100 basis points in terms of regulatory lag. Now, it's that's not evenly spread over the next years, so we do intend to start put that in place in 2015. So we are looking towards some improvement in that. It will the trajectory is again not credible, but will move up. So it's smaller in the first year.

At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Paul Johnson, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In a
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2014 Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition, we have other members of management team in the room to answer questions if necessary.
This morning, we will review our 2014 full year results, reaffirm our 2015 earnings guidance range, and update you on strategic plans and business -- that relate to business and regulatory developments. Slides that accompany today's call are available on our web page. In addition, we'll post a brief video on our website of Teresa summarizing our financial later this morning.
As a reminder, some of the comments during today's conference call may contain forward-looking information. Significant factors that could cause results to differ from those anticipated are described in our earnings release and our filings with the SEC.
I'll now turn the call over to Ben.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Paul, and good morning. I'm going to start by highlighting some of the key successes of 2014, and update you on some exciting developments Xcel Energy. Teresa will provide more detail on some of these items.2014 was another strong year for Xc
componenttext:
Thank you, Paul, and good morning. I'm going to start by highlighting some of the key successes of 2014, and update you on some exciting developments Xcel Energy. Teresa will provide more detail on some of these items.
2014 was another strong year for Xcel Energy, as the company recorded earnings of $2.03 per share. This marks the 10th consecutive year we've met or exceeded our earnings guidance. And a fifth consecutive year we've delivered earnings in the upper half of our guidance range.  In addition, we raised our dividend for the 11th year on a row.
From a regulatory perspective, we made significant progress wrapping rate cases at Wisconsin, New Mexico and Texas. We received a constructive ALJ recommendation in Minnesota. And most recently, reached a favorable 3-year settlement in our Colorado Electric case. When we filed the case in Colorado, we stated that our objective was to establish a multiyear regulatory plan that provides certainty for PSCo and its customers. This settlement accomplishes that goal, and provides us a reasonable opportunity to earn our authorized return in our Colorado Electric business over the next 3 years.
From an operational perspective, I also wanted to take a moment to say how incredibly proud I am of the efforts of our employees this year. We hit record levels of safety in 2014, improving for the seventh straight year. And again, we demonstrated our top-tier operating performance with industry-leading reliabilities scores.
Recall last quarter, we unveiled our refresh strategic plan that was focused on improving utility performance, including the goal of closing the ROE gap by 50 basis points, and increasing the amount of revenue generated from long-term regulatory agreements.  Driving operational excellence by focusing on limiting annual increases and O&M cost of between 0% and 2%. Providing our customers more options and solutions. And finally, investing for the future by focusing on incremental growth opportunities in our natural gas and transmission businesses.
Today, we're excited to update you on the progress we've made on some of these initiatives. The electric utility industry is in the midst of a major transition, and we're committed to being on the front end of this change. We will be a leader in the same way we proactively implemented our environmental strategy over a decade ago.
To this end, we are pursuing regulatory changes to better align with a clear direction that customer preferences, federal policies and state initiatives are moving. Last month, in Minnesota, a collaborative report was issued by a diverse stakeholder group known as the e21 Initiative. The group released a set of recommendations that are intended to act as a blueprint for a new customer-centric, performance-based regulatory approach.
Following e21 report, we filed with the Minnesota Commission a framework on how we envision enabling these changes. We focused on 4 key objectives: lowering carbon emission by 40% by 2030; pioneering in distribution grid monetization; responding to changing customer preferences and providing new services and products; and finally, pursuing more predictable and nimble rate recovery.
In order to effectively bring about these changes, it is essential that the company have a longer-term, more holistic regulatory compact. Longer-term, multiyear agreements and additional writers are expected to improve visibility and supplement our efforts. Further, the company has tools that can utilize to stabilize rate increases and make bills more printable for our customers. We expect to work with the commission and various stakeholders in Minnesota in 2015 who developed this new framework and have requested a planning meeting in the coming months to discuss potential options in greater detail.
We're also exploring ways for us to avoid the need to file a 2016 rate case, which will allow more time to concentrate on the longer-term regulatory framework.
In January, we filed our resource plan in Minnesota, which provides details on how we will achieve our commitment to reduce carbon emissions by 40% by 2030. This will be accomplished by significantly increasing the amount of solar and wind on the NSP system. Adding natural gas generation, continuing our industry-leading commitment to conservation programs, operating our nuclear plants at least through their current licenses, and continuing to run Sherco units 1 and 2 with gradual decreased reliance on those units through 2030.
This proactive, no-regret strategy will better position the company and our customers for the long run, and do so at an incremental cumulative cost of less than 3% through 2030. As a result, by 2030, 63% of our energy will be carbon-free at NSP. Clearly, 2015 is going to be a transformational year in Minnesota.
While much of our discussion is focused on Minnesota, we're also pursuing changes in our Texas jurisdiction. Along with other non-ERCOT utilities, we will be sponsoring legislation this session that will help reduce regulatory lag and allow us to continue to invest in a system to support growth in the region, which is continuing even in the phase of a challenging oil price environment.
Finally, we wanted to update you on our natural gas growth initiatives. As we mentioned last quarter, we plan to file a general rate case for our Colorado gas business. The filing will include a number of investments to maintain and improve the safety and reliability of our natural gas infrastructure.
Concurrent with our rate case, we will begin working with our commission and major stakeholders to explore rate-basing natural gas reserves as a way to take advantage of the current low natural gas price and to provide a longer-term hedge for our customers. Following our stakeholder and outreach and education, we expect to make a separate filing to begin the regulatory process. We're excited by the progress we've made and the steps we've taken thus far, and I look forward to updating you later this year.
So with that, I'll turn the call over to Teresa.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, I'll be focusing my discussion on full-year 2014 results. We are pleased to close out another solid year with ongoing earnings of $2.03 per share, compared with 2013 ongoing earnings of $1.95 per share.The most sign
componenttext:
Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, I'll be focusing my discussion on full-year 2014 results. We are pleased to close out another solid year with ongoing earnings of $2.03 per share, compared with 2013 ongoing earnings of $1.95 per share.
The most significant driver related to 2014 earnings was improved electric and natural gas margins that benefited from new rate and increased rider revenues in many of our jurisdictions. Increased margins more than offset an unfavorable weather comparison and higher O&M depreciation and property taxes. It is worth noting that the weather in 2014 contributed $0.03 per share when compared to normal. In contrast, in 2013, weather contributed $0.11 per share, resulting in a $0.08 per share decline when comparing the 2 years.
Now let me provide an update on sales and the economies in our local service territories. We experienced positive growth trends in 2014 with weather-normalized retail electric sales increasing 1.3% and firm natural gas sales improving 4.6%. Sales in 2014 exceeded our original expectations for the year. While we are monitoring economic conditions in our service territories and are closely watching potential implications from changes in the E&P space, we remain confident in our 2015 electric weather-adjusted sales growth assumption of 1%.
Let me provide a little more detail on sales growth by company. Beginning with NSP-Wisconsin, weather-adjusted retail sales increased 3.3% in 2014, due to strengthened C&I sales from growth in the sand mining industry and related oil and gas businesses. Customer growth and modest usage increases drove higher residential sales. Electric sales at SPS increased to 2.3% driven by growth in the C&I class.
Oil and gas exploration in the Permian Basin continues to benefit the service territory, and we saw additional growth in uranium enrichment. While we are watching the oil price closely and expect some producers to reduce new drilling activity, we anticipate that others will continue to grow production.
PSCo sales increased 1.2%, which was primarily attributable to strength in the C&I class due to new food manufacturing customers and energy sector growth. Finally, NSP-Minnesota sales increased 0.6% driven by growth in the number of residential and small C&I customers, and usage increases in the small C&I class.
Economic conditions remained strong across Xcel Energy service territories relative to the nation as a whole. The consolidated unemployment rate in our regions of 3.6% remains well below the national average of 5.4%. In addition, the number of jobs in our regions grew 2.3% during 2014, compared with 1.9% for the nation.
Focusing more specifically on 2014 earnings, ongoing electric margin increased $215 million. Key drivers included: implementation of final and interim rates, which increased margin by $129 million; nonfuel riders increased margin by $57 million, increased transmission investment, which improved margin by $31 million; and retail sales growth, excluding weather, improved margins by $24 million. These positive impacts were partially offset by an unfavorable weather comparison year-over-year of $60 million, as well as a few other items.
The electric margin results reflect an estimated refund obligation for the Minnesota rate case, which is relatively consistent with the recent ALJ recommendation; and an estimated customer refund liability to capture the impact of our electric earnings test at PSCo.
Margins on the natural gas side of the business increased by $49 million for the year. This is primarily due to rate release in Colorado, significant infrastructure investment that is captured in an annual rider and retail sales growth.
O&M expenses increased $61 million or 2.7% for 2014, solidly within our original guidance of 2% to 3% increase. The increase is primarily driven by higher, although moderating, nuclear costs. As we have discussed in the past, a key objective of our operational excellence strategic pillar is to limit O&M increases. We are reaffirming our 2015 O&M guidance of 0% to 2%, consistent with our long-term objective.
In addition, I think it's worth mentioning that our 2015 O&M guidance assumption reflects a lower pension discount rate and adoption of the recently updated mortality table. Finally, other [ph] taxes increased about $45 million or 11%, largely driven by higher property taxes in Minnesota, Texas and Colorado.
Next I'll update you on several regulatory proceedings. Additional details are included in our earnings release. In Colorado, we're pleased to have reached a settlement with parties that would successfully resolve our electric rate case. The agreement continues the productive, multiyear regulatory compact that we've been operating under since 2012. The settlement calls for a total increase of about $53 million or 1.9%, based on an ROE of 9.83% and an equity ratio of 56%. In addition, we anticipate that PSCo will differ about $3 million of expenses in 2015. The agreement also stipulates that both the clean air, clean jobs and transmission riders are forward-looking mechanisms.
It is worth noting that in our original Colorado rate case we had proposed shortening the depreciable life of certain assets, which would have led to a material increase in depreciation expense.  As a result of the settlement, PSCo will not be implementing the depreciation changes and will avoid this incremental depreciation expense. Alternatively, we agreed to file a standalone depreciation study early next year that will be incorporated into our next rate care anticipated in 2018. The commission is expected to rule out a settlement in the first quarter and rates are expected to be come effective in mid-February.
Last month, we received the ALJ recommendation in our Minnesota electric case. We were encouraged by the -- that they judge acknowledged the strength of the company's position on many of the key issues, including pension, benefits and depreciation. When including the ALJ's recommended ROE of 9.77% and adjusting for sales and property tax troughs, we estimate accumulative revenue increase of about $192 million for 2014 and 2015. Deliberations are currently scheduled for March.
Turning to our Monticello Prudence review, we have not yet received the ALJ recommendation. We believe the delay is related to work load issues for the ALJ and anticipate the ALJ recommendation in February. We continue to believe that we acted prudently in making decisions throughout the course of the project. In addition, the surrounding communities and our customers have a largely rebuilt, safe and efficient source of carbon-free, low-cost power for many years to come. Importantly, we don't believe that the delay in receiving the ALJ's recommendation will impact the current schedule, and we continue to expect the commission to deliberate on the proceeding in March.
In Texas, we filed a rate case requesting an increase in annual revenues of $65 million or 6.7%. Our filing reflects the inclusion of post-test year rate base additions, one of the items we are seeking legislative support for in Texas. New rates are expected to be implemented by mid-year. In South Dakota, we put interim rates of about $16 million in place on January 1, and continue to work through the regulatory process. Final rates are expected to be approved mid-year.
We also made progress on several other initiatives during the fourth quarter. In Wisconsin, the commission approved the settlement agreement, which we reached last year with staff and intervenors for a rate increase of $14 million or 2.2%. Rates went into effect earlier this month.
In Texas, the commission approved our settlement in the 2014 rate case, providing incremental revenue of $37 million or 3.5%. Rates went into effect retroactive to June 2014.
Finally, in Minnesota, the commission approved our gas infrastructure writer for $15 million with rates becoming effective in February 2015. In summary, 2014 was a busy and productive year for us on the regulatory front.
This morning, we are reaffirming our 2015 earnings guidance of $2 to $2.15 per share. Our guidance range is based on several key assumptions as described in our earnings release, including constructive outcomes in our regulatory proceedings. Please note that some of the assumptions have changed due primarily to incorporating actual 2014 results.
With that, I'll wrap up my comments. After a solid 2014, we are pleased to deliver earnings within our guidance range for the 10th consecutive year. We are reaffirming our 2015 earnings guidance range of $2 to $2.15 per share, our 5-year capital plan of $14.5 billion and our 4.7% rate base CAGR, even when considering the impacts from the recently passed bonus depreciation legislation.
We continue to see improved economic conditions in our regions, and experienced better-than-expected sales growth, with 2014 weather-adjusted retail electric sales growth of 1.3% and weather adjusted firm natural gas sales growth of 4.6%. We are making meaningful progress on the regulatory front, including the recent multiyear settlement in Colorado, and expect to reach a conclusion in the Minnesota case in the next few months.
We delivered 2014 O&M expense growth within our guidance of 2% to 3% and continue to expect 2015 O&M to be flat to 2%.
And finally, we are well-positioned to deliver an attractive long-term value to our shareholders by growing earnings and our dividend 4% to 6% annually.
So with that, operator, we'll now take questions.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question today from Michael Weinstein, UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first question today from Michael Weinstein, UBS.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Perhaps first, if you can, you talked a lot about the future here. You talked about the IRP. Can you perhaps comment on the ability for Xcel to take advantage of opportunities, perhaps in solar, in the near term and perhaps in the long term? And perhaps a
componenttext: Perhaps first, if you can, you talked a lot about the future here. You talked about the IRP. Can you perhaps comment on the ability for Xcel to take advantage of opportunities, perhaps in solar, in the near term and perhaps in the long term? And perhaps also, at the same time, elaborate -- you introduced a comment other products and services, perhaps could you elaborate a little bit on what you meant there as well?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. We're going to add, obviously, as part of that, the resource plan, a tremendous amount of renewables, both wind and solar. A lot of it comes from in the '20 through '30 time frame. I think that gives us a great opportunity to own a good piece of tho
componenttext: Sure. We're going to add, obviously, as part of that, the resource plan, a tremendous amount of renewables, both wind and solar. A lot of it comes from in the '20 through '30 time frame. I think that gives us a great opportunity to own a good piece of those investment opportunities for a couple of reasons. One, clearly, technology will come down and it will most likely not have as much of the federal tax incentives that it does have now. Two, our tax appetite should grow in coming years. So I think we should be well positioned to take advantage of some of those opportunities. Your second question was regarding ...

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I suppose you've made this curious comment about offering other products and services. I'm just curious if there's anything tangible?
componenttext: I suppose you've made this curious comment about offering other products and services. I'm just curious if there's anything tangible?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it's -- there's a number of things that we want to do. I mean, increasingly, customers want a different energy mix. They want greener products. They want different billing options. It's basically just responding to the trend that we've seen t
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it's -- there's a number of things that we want to do. I mean, increasingly, customers want a different energy mix. They want greener products. They want different billing options. It's basically just responding to the trend that we've seen that consumers one-size-fits-all, which has been the traditional utility role, needs the change. And we want to work with our -- the commission and their staffs to make sure that we do that in a way that's fair to all and be fixable enough to move forward with that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Excellent. And just -- if you don't mind commenting on transmission here. I'd be curious, where does your transco strategy stand, given some commentary from peers and the SPP market overall of perhaps a lackluster spend trajectory here at least for 2015?
componenttext: Excellent. And just -- if you don't mind commenting on transmission here. I'd be curious, where does your transco strategy stand, given some commentary from peers and the SPP market overall of perhaps a lackluster spend trajectory here at least for 2015? How does that jive with what your baking into expectations and your own expectations for longer-term buildout of the transco? And perhaps a clarification on the last question, does that mean for solar? It's kind of an opportunity for you all post the '16 ITC. Is that what I'm hearing from you?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It means that it would be -- that the opportunity improves significantly. It doesn't mean we can't do something before that. But as you know, renewables are heavily driven by tax appetites, and you need one to efficiently -- it doesn't mean you're fully p
componenttext: It means that it would be -- that the opportunity improves significantly. It doesn't mean we can't do something before that. But as you know, renewables are heavily driven by tax appetites, and you need one to efficiently -- it doesn't mean you're fully precluded, but to efficiently participate in those markets. Your question was about transcos and transmission. Well, keep in mind that $4.5 billion of our CapEx over the next 5 years is in transmission. None of it is in the transco or -- and none of it assumes that we win any of the competitive transmission projects. So when you look at what's come out of SPP and their ITP10 plan, I think it was about $300-odd million of potential opportunities. By the way, it looks like a -- not an insignificant amount of that would go into the -- to SPS. But we don't have -- that does not impact. That would be the icing on the cake. So our strategy is always been two prong. We have the utility vehicle to invest in, that's where we are today. We're in the process of getting approvals, final approvals on our transco, so that we can participate in those competitive markets. I think we're well-positioned to do that. It's gone a little bit slower, as you mentioned, than I think many people thought. It doesn't really surprise us. I think there'll be more opportunities in the years to come. And again, I think we'll be very well-positioned to win in those markets.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: But to summarize, do you feel confident in the $4.5 billion you already delineated and executing on that despite, perhaps, a little bit of the lacklusterness in FPP, et cetera?
componenttext: But to summarize, do you feel confident in the $4.5 billion you already delineated and executing on that despite, perhaps, a little bit of the lacklusterness in FPP, et cetera?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Those by and large identified projects. So yes, we feel very confident in that.
componenttext: Those by and large identified projects. So yes, we feel very confident in that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ali Agha with SunTrust is next.
componenttext: Ali Agha with SunTrust is next.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you remind me -- in your '15 guidance range right now, what kind of regulatory lag is assumed there? And best case scenario, how much of that do you think you can ultimately capture?
componenttext: Can you remind me -- in your '15 guidance range right now, what kind of regulatory lag is assumed there? And best case scenario, how much of that do you think you can ultimately capture?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, just historically, we've been running about 100 basis points in terms of regulatory lag. And as we talked about as one of our priorities is we intend to close that gap at 50 basis points. That's our target. Now, that's not evenly spread over the n
componenttext: I mean, just historically, we've been running about 100 basis points in terms of regulatory lag. And as we talked about as one of our priorities is we intend to close that gap at 50 basis points. That's our target. Now, that's not evenly spread over the next years, but we do intend to start to put that in place in 2015. So we are looking towards some improvement in that. It will -- the trajectory is, again, not radical, but will move up. So it's smaller in the first year.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: But to be clear, Teresa, the starting point in '15, I think, the $2 to $2.15 guidance, that is still assuming at the midpoint of about 100 basis point lag?
componenttext: But to be clear, Teresa, the starting point in '15, I think, the $2 to $2.15 guidance, that is still assuming at the midpoint of about 100 basis point lag?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a little bit -- it's right around there. We've assumed just a slight piece.
componenttext: Yes, it's a little bit -- it's right around there. We've assumed just a slight piece.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then my second question, as you mentioned, you ran -- weather-normalized electric sales were up 1.3% in '14, ahead of perhaps your original plan. But I noticed that for '15, you're still assuming 1%,  and I think for gas, you're actually assuming a
componenttext: Okay. Then my second question, as you mentioned, you ran -- weather-normalized electric sales were up 1.3% in '14, ahead of perhaps your original plan. But I noticed that for '15, you're still assuming 1%,  and I think for gas, you're actually assuming a 2% decline. So why the slowdown in electric? Or what are you seeing in '15 that causes you to be more cautious?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're just being conservative in terms of our overall outlook in terms of 2015. As we've talked to you -- and this goes for gas too, in previous quarters. Early in the year, we had some extreme weather and we're always concerned. We had a little bit of we
componenttext: We're just being conservative in terms of our overall outlook in terms of 2015. As we've talked to you -- and this goes for gas too, in previous quarters. Early in the year, we had some extreme weather and we're always concerned. We had a little bit of weather wrapped up in our overall sales, so both in the electric and gas business. So we're just being conservative, Ali, in saying that. It's not any significant item that's driving us to keep it at that level, the 1%.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I just wanted to be clear, the comments you made that in your next Colorado gas case, you do plan to also ask to put some of your gas reserves into rate base. Can you remind us, if that happens, what kind of incremental rate base does that
componenttext: Okay. And then I just wanted to be clear, the comments you made that in your next Colorado gas case, you do plan to also ask to put some of your gas reserves into rate base. Can you remind us, if that happens, what kind of incremental rate base does that mean? And also, what is the mechanism? I wasn't clear. Is it part of the rate case? Is it a separate filing? Just wanted to be clear on how this goes.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know if we're actually going to talk very much about in the actual case that will file to get recovery of core infrastructure investments, Ali. What I said is that -- we would do a concurrent filing, a separate filing that will take place mos
componenttext: Yes, I don't know if we're actually going to talk very much about in the actual case that will file to get recovery of core infrastructure investments, Ali. What I said is that -- we would do a concurrent filing, a separate filing that will take place most likely in the second half of this year. We're going to gather stakeholders input, understand what the important issues with our stakeholders are. Assuming those conversations and the filing goes well, and I assume they'll be kind of open-type meetings, then look for us to pursue a defined and more fleshed out plan, obviously, in the 2016 time frame. We purchase about 450 Bcf a year. So what is that? At $3, it's about $1.2 billion of gas. Obviously, we wouldn't do it all, so you'd have -- you would lay into it slowly, I think with the emphasis more on our LDC gas business in Colorado.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. But just the mechanism, I mean, if it moves into rate base, you'd want rate increases to reflect that. So would that be sort of put in as part of this rate case filing? Would that be a separate rate case? How would the rates be adjusted if you do ge
componenttext: Okay. But just the mechanism, I mean, if it moves into rate base, you'd want rate increases to reflect that. So would that be sort of put in as part of this rate case filing? Would that be a separate rate case? How would the rates be adjusted if you do get it into rate base?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would be separate. And it -- what we're -- the whole premise is it's fuel for rate base. And so how that mechanism would be determined, there's different models out there, as I think you're aware. And we would -- that's the kind of input we want from s
componenttext: It would be separate. And it -- what we're -- the whole premise is it's fuel for rate base. And so how that mechanism would be determined, there's different models out there, as I think you're aware. And we would -- that's the kind of input we want from stakeholders to understand, what risk they're willing to bear and which risk they're not willing to bear, and then we can move forward accordingly.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And final question. In the past event, you also talked about looking at opportunities where you have current PPAs that may be expiring, that -- is there an opportunity to rate base some of those plants? As we look at calendar 2015, just looking at w
componenttext: Okay. And final question. In the past event, you also talked about looking at opportunities where you have current PPAs that may be expiring, that -- is there an opportunity to rate base some of those plants? As we look at calendar 2015, just looking at where you are in terms of contracts, et cetera, are there opportunities that could play out this year? Or is this something that we should think about beyond 2015?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think there is always opportunities. I mean -- and we're always looking for those opportunities, to your point. And so, I can't promise anything, but we certainly are diligently looking at those opportunities.
componenttext: No, I think there is always opportunities. I mean -- and we're always looking for those opportunities, to your point. And so, I can't promise anything, but we certainly are diligently looking at those opportunities.

componenttext: It could.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is on cap spending. Your -- and I'm referring to the slides you brought to my conference a couple of weeks ago. They're pretty consistent, I think, with prior disclosures. You got a $3.375 billion spend in '15, declines to more or le
componenttext: Okay. Second question is on cap spending. Your -- and I'm referring to the slides you brought to my conference a couple of weeks ago. They're pretty consistent, I think, with prior disclosures. You got a $3.375 billion spend in '15, declines to more or less $2.8 billion in '16, '17, then dips a little bit in '18, comes back up in '19. And so that averages $4.7, but that's kind of front-end loaded. And then you made these subsequent filings in Minnesota, specifically on resource planning. So is the bias to potentially see if you get buy in Minnesota, to see that sort of '17, '18, '19 spend potentially go up?

componenttextpreview: Well, maybe I'll just start in terms of the spend. While we have that peak, just as a reminder, Greg, I mean, it's is the wind in Minnesota, the 2 wind farms that will go in service. So that's -- that is really the peak up. And then in terms of relative t
componenttext: Well, maybe I'll just start in terms of the spend. While we have that peak, just as a reminder, Greg, I mean, it's is the wind in Minnesota, the 2 wind farms that will go in service. So that's -- that is really the peak up. And then in terms of relative to going forward, that we, once rates would changed, assuming they do, we should level off in terms of our relative increases. But we do have the initial peak.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess, I'm asking, I know you're working -- you have rate plans to smooth in those increases. My question goes more towards the overall level of cap spending, which declines as you get out into '17, '18, '19.
componenttext: Right. I guess, I'm asking, I know you're working -- you have rate plans to smooth in those increases. My question goes more towards the overall level of cap spending, which declines as you get out into '17, '18, '19.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, typically, Greg -- and there's obviously no guarantee. But as you know, as we get into those outyears, they tend -- the actual spend has historically tended to increase as we identified new opportunities or new needs within our spending parameters
componenttext: I mean, typically, Greg -- and there's obviously no guarantee. But as you know, as we get into those outyears, they tend -- the actual spend has historically tended to increase as we identified new opportunities or new needs within our spending parameters. And I think we'll -- I think you also were asking about the resource plan itself that we filed in -- as I said, I think that could create some opportunities for us, albeit most of them would be in the latter part of that 5-year forecast or even outside of that 5-year forecast.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. So the -- when we think about your 5% to 7% growth aspiration, this plan drives orders slightly less in terms of rate-based growth, and then improving regulatory lag, too, inside the range. Should you, in fact, identify more cap spending than tha
componenttext: Got you. So the -- when we think about your 5% to 7% growth aspiration, this plan drives orders slightly less in terms of rate-based growth, and then improving regulatory lag, too, inside the range. Should you, in fact, identify more cap spending than that? Or sort of the calculus just moves up a little bit?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've tempered back the 5% to 7% to be closer to around 5% rate-based growth as we look forward. So it's a little bit lower than the 5% to 7% as we had in past years, I've talked about.
componenttext: Yes, we've tempered back the 5% to 7% to be closer to around 5% rate-based growth as we look forward. So it's a little bit lower than the 5% to 7% as we had in past years, I've talked about.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we always look for rate base opportunities, Greg, to your point. And also to your point, the thing that will really drive earnings and closing that ROE gap, as Teresa mentioned, I think we're making good progress on that. I am -- we're excited about co
componenttext: So we always look for rate base opportunities, Greg, to your point. And also to your point, the thing that will really drive earnings and closing that ROE gap, as Teresa mentioned, I think we're making good progress on that. I am -- we're excited about continuing what has been a good deal for customers and shareholders in Colorado, and I'm encouraged with the progress we're making here in Minnesota.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Great. And then final question is last year you raised the dividend the first quarter, whereas in the prior years, you had raised it later in the year. What is the -- your expectation of the current dividend cycle this year and going forward?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we address that with the board. And so that you probably can assume that last year's cycle would be more consistent going forward.
componenttext: Well, I mean, we address that with the board. And so that you probably can assume that last year's cycle would be more consistent going forward.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015

componenttext: Our next question will come from Travis Miller with Morningstar.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about impact on you guys from the oil price drop? And how that might be incorporated or not in that 1% demand forecast, anything around that would have a material impact?
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about impact on you guys from the oil price drop? And how that might be incorporated or not in that 1% demand forecast, anything around that would have a material impact?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, let me start and I'll let Teresa add if she thinks I've missed anything. I mean, one is, Teresa mentioned, we've got a -- 1% is probably, all things equal, fairly conservative sales forecast. So we have margin -- reserve margin, if you will. But
componenttext: I guess, let me start and I'll let Teresa add if she thinks I've missed anything. I mean, one is, Teresa mentioned, we've got a -- 1% is probably, all things equal, fairly conservative sales forecast. So we have margin -- reserve margin, if you will. But actually, we don't really see much in the way of -- we do sales coming out of the decline in oil prices. And to the extent we do, keep in mind that, that is probably the lowest margin part of our business. So I don't think it's a big impact, Travis. I really don't. And we don't think is going to be a big impact on our spending -- capital spending profile either.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And one on the Colorado case, on the electric side. How much, given the adjustments you were able to get out of the clear aircon [ph] jobs and the transmission into riders and such. How much now, if you can give a sense on a percentage basis
componenttext: Okay, great. And one on the Colorado case, on the electric side. How much, given the adjustments you were able to get out of the clear aircon [ph] jobs and the transmission into riders and such. How much now, if you can give a sense on a percentage basis or idea, is subject to demand? Demand sensitive in terms of our earning ROE.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of -- oh, in terms of just the sales growth?
componenttext: In terms of -- oh, in terms of just the sales growth?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, needing sales growth to compensate for the net capital investment that you guys would see over this 3-year period?
componenttext: Yes, needing sales growth to compensate for the net capital investment that you guys would see over this 3-year period?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's very moderate in terms of that. Because those were our biggest drivers in terms of that cost recovery and having those mechanisms in place. We are definitely predicting sales growth, but it's not dependent in terms of earning our ROE and havi
componenttext: I think it's very moderate in terms of that. Because those were our biggest drivers in terms of that cost recovery and having those mechanisms in place. We are definitely predicting sales growth, but it's not dependent in terms of earning our ROE and having a -- an aggressive sales growth achievement.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow-up on the e21 Initiative. You mentioned that you came out with the initial kind of blueprint back in December, and then you actually filed with the NTEC this month for a specific rider mechanism of some kind. You were a little bit kind
componenttext: I wanted to follow-up on the e21 Initiative. You mentioned that you came out with the initial kind of blueprint back in December, and then you actually filed with the NTEC this month for a specific rider mechanism of some kind. You were a little bit kind of high-level with the description there. I wanted to find that a little bit more in a way of detail, and find out more in a way of timing. And then also, I wanted to understand the interplay between that request and then the fact that you've kind of bundled in some futuristic carbon goals as well, kind of how do those 2 relate within that request?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, to try to answer that, it's all about having a longer-term approach to what we're trying to accomplish in Minnesota. So the resource plan we went out further, here is what we can do by 2030. Here's how we get there. Let's focus on the key o
componenttext: Well, I guess, to try to answer that, it's all about having a longer-term approach to what we're trying to accomplish in Minnesota. So the resource plan we went out further, here is what we can do by 2030. Here's how we get there. Let's focus on the key objective, which is carbon reduction. Let's be very disciplined about how we achieve that carbon reduction using what, we like to call, technologies at the speed of value. So disciplined on how we approach it. And let's make sure that our regulatory compact reflects that longer-term view. So yes, we outline general frameworks. But generally, what we're looking for is longer-term regulatory compacts. We'd like to see compacts 3, 4, maybe even up to 5 years long. And within -- in that, things you can augment that with riders, you could use [indiscernible] recovery-type mechanisms, and then have the incentives for achieving what I think the state wants us to achieve. So we left it deliberately big, but we are building off that e21 Initiative, which we participated in, but we didn't drive. So I think -- I really think there is an excitement here in Minnesota as we've outlined these plans and talked about how we can achieve these carbon reduction goals at are very, very modest price to consumers. So more to come on that, but I think it's pretty exciting time.

componenttext: Yes. Well, let me just say that I had the opportunity, as have others on the Xcel team, to talk about what we're trying to accomplish. And as I mentioned, it's -- I think there's a lot of excitement. And I think there is -- the devil is always in the details, as you know. But I think there's a lot of excitement that this is a way we ought to be going in the state. So that's from a regulatory perspective, we'd like to potentially have legislation that would support that new regulatory framework in Minnesota. So more to come on that, obviously. In Texas, I think we're getting some traction. It's still a little bit early days. They haven't even assigned -- made committees assignments to the key committees that would drive legislation for us. But we haven't seen any major roadblocks at this point.

componenttext: Yes, let me take a stab at it. I mean, first of all, where there's a will, there's a way. And I think -- as I said, I think there's really a will to lets get the 2016 case out of the way and let's focus on this longer-term framework. So how would we do that mechanically? Well, it starts with using the ALJ recommendations. Getting our interim rate proposal adopted close to what we have proposed. And then, taking a look at our excess depreciation and maybe the reshaping that a bit, along with using some of our nuclear depreciation as well. So there's a way, Jonathan. And it would be nice to free up the time so we could spend more time on these other more longer-term ideas that have led the community and we have.
