headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, just historically, we've been running about 100 basis points in terms of regulatory lag. And as we talked about as one of our priorities is we intend to close that gap to 50 basis points. That's our target. Now, that's not evenly spread over the n
componenttext: I mean, just historically, we've been running about 100 basis points in terms of regulatory lag. And as we talked about as one of our priorities is we intend to close that gap to 50 basis points. That's our target. Now, that's not evenly spread over the next years, but we do intend to start to put that in place in 2015. So we are working towards some improvement in that. It will -- the trajectory is, again, not ratable but will move up. So it's smaller in the first year.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: But to be clear, Teresa, the starting point in '15, I think, the $2 to $2.15 guidance, that is still assuming at the midpoint about a 100 basis point lag?
componenttext: But to be clear, Teresa, the starting point in '15, I think, the $2 to $2.15 guidance, that is still assuming at the midpoint about a 100 basis point lag?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a little bit -- it's right around there. We've assumed just a slight piece.
componenttext: Yes, it's a little bit -- it's right around there. We've assumed just a slight piece.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then my second question, as you mentioned, you ran -- weather-normalized electric sales were up 1.3% in '14, ahead of perhaps your original plan. But I noticed that for '15, you're still assuming 1%. And I think for gas, you're actually assuming a 2
componenttext: Okay. Then my second question, as you mentioned, you ran -- weather-normalized electric sales were up 1.3% in '14, ahead of perhaps your original plan. But I noticed that for '15, you're still assuming 1%. And I think for gas, you're actually assuming a 2% decline. So why the slowdown in electric? Or what are you seeing in '15 that causes you to be more cautious?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're just being conservative in terms of our overall outlook in terms of 2015. As we've talked to you -- and this goes for gas, too, in previous quarters. Early in the year, we had some extreme weather, and we were always concerned we had a little bit of
componenttext: We're just being conservative in terms of our overall outlook in terms of 2015. As we've talked to you -- and this goes for gas, too, in previous quarters. Early in the year, we had some extreme weather, and we were always concerned we had a little bit of weather wrapped up in our overall sales, so both in the electric and gas business. So we're just being conservative, Ali, in saying that. It's not any significant item that's driving us to keep it at that level, the 1%.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I want to be clear, the comment you made that, in your next Colorado gas case, you do plan to also ask to put some of your gas reserves into rate base. Can you remind us, if that happens, what kind of incremental rate base does that mean? A
componenttext: Okay. And then I want to be clear, the comment you made that, in your next Colorado gas case, you do plan to also ask to put some of your gas reserves into rate base. Can you remind us, if that happens, what kind of incremental rate base does that mean? And also, what is the mechanism? I wasn't clear. Is it part of the rate case? Is it a separate filing? Just want to be clear on how this goes.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't know if we're actually going to talk very much about it in the actual case that we'll file to get recovery of core infrastructure investments, Ali. What I said is that we would do a concurrent filing, a separate filing that will take place mo
componenttext: Yes, I don't know if we're actually going to talk very much about it in the actual case that we'll file to get recovery of core infrastructure investments, Ali. What I said is that we would do a concurrent filing, a separate filing that will take place most likely in the second half of this year. We're going to gather stakeholder input, understand what the important issues with our stakeholders are. Assuming those conversations and the filing goes well, and I assume they'll be kind of open-type meetings, then look for us to pursue a defined and more fleshed-out plan, obviously, in the 2016 time frame. We purchase about 450 Bcf a year. So what is that? At $3, it's about $1.2 billion of gas. Obviously, we wouldn't do it all, so we'd have -- you would lay into it slowly, I think, with the emphasis more on our LDC gas business in Colorado.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. But just the mechanism, I mean, if it moves into rate base, you'd want rate increases to reflect that. So would that be sort of put in as part of this rate case filing? Would that be a separate rate case? How would the rates be adjusted if you do ge
componenttext: Okay. But just the mechanism, I mean, if it moves into rate base, you'd want rate increases to reflect that. So would that be sort of put in as part of this rate case filing? Would that be a separate rate case? How would the rates be adjusted if you do get it into rate base?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It would be separate. And it -- what we're -- the whole premise is it's fuel for rate base. And so how that mechanism would be determined, there's different models out there, as I think you're aware. And we would -- that's the kind of input we want from s
componenttext: It would be separate. And it -- what we're -- the whole premise is it's fuel for rate base. And so how that mechanism would be determined, there's different models out there, as I think you're aware. And we would -- that's the kind of input we want from stakeholders to understand what risk they're willing to bear and which risk they're not willing to bear, and then we can move forward accordingly.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And final question. In the past, Ben, you also talked about looking at opportunities where you have current PPAs that may be expiring that -- is there an opportunity to rate base some of those plants? As we look at calendar 2015, just looking at whe
componenttext: Okay. And final question. In the past, Ben, you also talked about looking at opportunities where you have current PPAs that may be expiring that -- is there an opportunity to rate base some of those plants? As we look at calendar 2015, just looking at where you are in terms of contracts, et cetera, are there opportunities that could play out this year? Or is this something that we should think about beyond 2015?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, I think there is always opportunities. I mean -- and we're always looking for those opportunities, to your point. And so, I can't promise anything, but we certainly are diligently looking at those opportunities.
componenttext: No, I think there is always opportunities. I mean -- and we're always looking for those opportunities, to your point. And so, I can't promise anything, but we certainly are diligently looking at those opportunities.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It could happen this year if something comes together?
componenttext: It could happen this year if something comes together?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It could.
componenttext: It could.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Greg Gordon, Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Greg Gordon, Evercore ISI.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: First question is on the Colorado rate case. How much of a depreciation increase had you initially asked for that was subsequently removed in the context of the settlement?
componenttext: First question is on the Colorado rate case. How much of a depreciation increase had you initially asked for that was subsequently removed in the context of the settlement?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Greg, it was north of $30 million. So...
componenttext: Greg, it was north of $30 million. So...

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is on cap spending. Your -- and I'm referring to the slides you brought to my conference a couple of weeks ago. They're pretty consistent, I think, with prior disclosures. You've had a $3.375 billion spend in '15, declines to more or
componenttext: Okay. Second question is on cap spending. Your -- and I'm referring to the slides you brought to my conference a couple of weeks ago. They're pretty consistent, I think, with prior disclosures. You've had a $3.375 billion spend in '15, declines to more or less $2.8 billion in '16, '17, then dips a little bit in '18, comes back up in '19. And so that averages $4.7, but it's kind of front-end loaded. And then you've made these subsequent filings in Minnesota, specifically on resource planning. So is the bias to potentially see, if you can get by in Minnesota, to see that sort of '17, '18, '19 spend potentially go up?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, maybe I'll just start in terms of the spend. Why we have that peak, just as a reminder, Greg, I mean, it's the wind in Minnesota, the 2 wind farms that will go in service. So that's -- that is really the peak up. And then in terms of relative to goi
componenttext: Well, maybe I'll just start in terms of the spend. Why we have that peak, just as a reminder, Greg, I mean, it's the wind in Minnesota, the 2 wind farms that will go in service. So that's -- that is really the peak up. And then in terms of relative to going forward, that we -- once rates would change, assuming they do, we should level off in terms of our relative increases. But we do have the initial peak.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess I'm asking, I know you're working -- you have a rate plan to smooth in those increases. My question goes more towards the overall level of cap spending, which declines as you get out into '17, '18, '19.
componenttext: Right. I guess I'm asking, I know you're working -- you have a rate plan to smooth in those increases. My question goes more towards the overall level of cap spending, which declines as you get out into '17, '18, '19.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, typically, Greg -- and there's obviously no guarantee. But as you know, as we get into those out-years, they tend -- the actual spend has historically tended to increase as we identify new opportunities or new needs within our spending parameters.
componenttext: I mean, typically, Greg -- and there's obviously no guarantee. But as you know, as we get into those out-years, they tend -- the actual spend has historically tended to increase as we identify new opportunities or new needs within our spending parameters. And I think we'll -- I think you were also asking about the resource plan itself that we filed. And as I said, I think that could create some opportunities for us, albeit most of them would be in the latter part of that 5-year forecast or even outside of that 5-year forecast.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Got you. So the -- when we think about your 5% to 7% growth aspiration, this plan drives towards slightly less in terms of rate base growth and then improving regulatory lag to inside the range. But should you, in fact, identify more cap spending than tha
componenttext: Got you. So the -- when we think about your 5% to 7% growth aspiration, this plan drives towards slightly less in terms of rate base growth and then improving regulatory lag to inside the range. But should you, in fact, identify more cap spending than that, the whole sort of calculus just moves up a little bit?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've tempered back the 5% to 7% to be closer to around 5% rate base growth as we look forward. So it's a little bit lower than the 5% to 7% as we, in past years, had talked about.
componenttext: Yes, we've tempered back the 5% to 7% to be closer to around 5% rate base growth as we look forward. So it's a little bit lower than the 5% to 7% as we, in past years, had talked about.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we always look for rate base opportunities, Greg, to your point. And also to your point, the thing that will really drive earnings is in closing that ROE gap, as Teresa mentioned, I think, we're making good progress on that. I mean, we're excited about
componenttext: So we always look for rate base opportunities, Greg, to your point. And also to your point, the thing that will really drive earnings is in closing that ROE gap, as Teresa mentioned, I think, we're making good progress on that. I mean, we're excited about continuing what has been a good deal for customers and shareholders in Colorado, and I'm encouraged with the progress we're making here in Minnesota.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And then the final question is, last year, you raised the dividend that first quarter, whereas in prior years, you had raised it later in the year. What is the -- your expectation of the current dividend cycle this year and going forward?
componenttext: Great. And then the final question is, last year, you raised the dividend that first quarter, whereas in prior years, you had raised it later in the year. What is the -- your expectation of the current dividend cycle this year and going forward?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we address that with the board. And so that you probably can assume that last year's cycle will be more consistent going forward.
componenttext: Well, I mean, we address that with the board. And so that you probably can assume that last year's cycle will be more consistent going forward.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Travis Miller with Morningstar.
componenttext: Our next question will come from Travis Miller with Morningstar.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about the impact on you guys from the oil price drop and how that might be incorporated or not in that 1% demand forecast, anything around that, that would have a material impact?
componenttext: I'm wondering if you could talk a little bit about the impact on you guys from the oil price drop and how that might be incorporated or not in that 1% demand forecast, anything around that, that would have a material impact?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, let me start, and I'll let Teresa add if she thinks I've missed anything. I mean, one, as Teresa mentioned, we've got a -- 1% is probably, all things equal, fairly conservative sales forecast. So we have margin -- reserve margin, if you will. But
componenttext: I guess, let me start, and I'll let Teresa add if she thinks I've missed anything. I mean, one, as Teresa mentioned, we've got a -- 1% is probably, all things equal, fairly conservative sales forecast. So we have margin -- reserve margin, if you will. But actually, we don't really see much in the way of reduced sales coming out of the decline in oil prices. And to the extent we do, keep in mind that, that is probably the lowest-margin part of our business. So I don't think it's a big impact, Travis. I really don't. And we don't think is going to be a big impact on our spending -- capital spending profile either.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And one on the Colorado case, on the electric side. How much, given the adjustments you were able to get out of the clean air, clean jobs and the transmission into riders and such, how much now, if you can give a sense on a percentage basis o
componenttext: Okay, great. And one on the Colorado case, on the electric side. How much, given the adjustments you were able to get out of the clean air, clean jobs and the transmission into riders and such, how much now, if you can give a sense on a percentage basis or idea, is subject to demand -- demand-sensitive in terms of our earning ROE?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: In terms of -- oh, in terms of just the sales growth?
componenttext: In terms of -- oh, in terms of just the sales growth?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, needing sales growth to compensate for the net capital investment that you guys would see over this 3-year period?
componenttext: Yes, needing sales growth to compensate for the net capital investment that you guys would see over this 3-year period?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's very moderate in terms of that. Because those were our biggest drivers in terms of that cost recovery. And having those mechanisms in place, we are definitely predicting sales growth, but it's not dependent in terms of -- our ROE on having an
componenttext: I think it's very moderate in terms of that. Because those were our biggest drivers in terms of that cost recovery. And having those mechanisms in place, we are definitely predicting sales growth, but it's not dependent in terms of -- our ROE on having an aggressive sales growth achievement.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, I would agree with that, what Teresa said. I mean, of course, the riders help with the incremental, but I mean, you got your core business, so sales growth is always an issue. But I think we have that reasonably pegged. And to Teresa's point, we'r
componenttext: I mean, I would agree with that, what Teresa said. I mean, of course, the riders help with the incremental, but I mean, you got your core business, so sales growth is always an issue. But I think we have that reasonably pegged. And to Teresa's point, we're not assuming an aggressive sales forecast in those numbers.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Next is Chris Turnure, JPMorgan.
componenttext: Next is Chris Turnure, JPMorgan.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to follow up on the e21 Initiative. You mentioned that you came out with the initial kind of blueprint back in December and then you actually filed with the NTEC this month for a specific rider mechanism of some kind. You were a little bit kind o
componenttext: I wanted to follow up on the e21 Initiative. You mentioned that you came out with the initial kind of blueprint back in December and then you actually filed with the NTEC this month for a specific rider mechanism of some kind. You were a little bit kind of high-level with the description there. I wanted to find out a little bit more in the way of detail and find out more in the way of timing. And also, I wanted to understand the interplay between that request and then the fact that you've kind of bundled in some futuristic carbon goals as well, kind of how do those 2 relate within that request?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, to try to answer that, it's all about having a longer-term approach to what we're trying to accomplish in Minnesota. So the resource plan, we went out further, here is what we can do by 2030. Here's how we get there. Let's focus on the key
componenttext: Well, I guess, to try to answer that, it's all about having a longer-term approach to what we're trying to accomplish in Minnesota. So the resource plan, we went out further, here is what we can do by 2030. Here's how we get there. Let's focus on the key objective, which is carbon reduction. Let's be very disciplined about how we achieve that carbon reduction using what we like to call technologies at the speed of value. So disciplined on how we approach it, and let's make sure that our regulatory compact reflects that longer-term view. So yes, we outline general frameworks. But generally, what we're looking for is longer-term regulatory compacts. We'd like to see compacts 3, 4, maybe even up to 5 years long. And within -- in that, things -- you can augment that with riders, you could use formulaic recovery-type mechanisms and then have the incentives for achieving what I think the state wants us to achieve. So we left it deliberately vague, but we are building off that e21 Initiative, which we participated in but we didn't drive. So I think -- I really think there is an excitement here in Minnesota as we've outlined these plans and talked about how we can achieve these carbon reduction goals at a very, very modest price to consumers. So more to come on that, but I think it's a pretty exciting time.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to add to that. I mean -- and just to clarify, Ben outlined the framework, but I think you mentioned that we had made a rider request. We haven't specifically done that. So just to add to Ben's comment in terms of the overall framework.
componenttext: Maybe just to add to that. I mean -- and just to clarify, Ben outlined the framework, but I think you mentioned that we had made a rider request. We haven't specifically done that. So just to add to Ben's comment in terms of the overall framework.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Got you. So nothing specific with the rider request. And then just stepping back, overall, this is more driven by future growth, future spending demands and initiatives, and then those are going to potentially necessitate some kind of rider or catch
componenttext: Okay. Got you. So nothing specific with the rider request. And then just stepping back, overall, this is more driven by future growth, future spending demands and initiatives, and then those are going to potentially necessitate some kind of rider or catch-up mechanism to compensate you for that?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there are different ways you can get there. So the point is that we're moving to a different environment, and we're going to need the regulatory compact to evolve with it. And so -- I mean, the key takeaway I hope you get is that what we're really s
componenttext: Well, there are different ways you can get there. So the point is that we're moving to a different environment, and we're going to need the regulatory compact to evolve with it. And so -- I mean, the key takeaway I hope you get is that what we're really seeking is a more comprehensive multiyear approach.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then do you have any color around kind of initial conversations there with regulators and then kind of separately, in either Minnesota or in Texas, initial conversations with policy-makers and the timing around your legislative initiatives in bo
componenttext: Okay. And then do you have any color around kind of initial conversations there with regulators and then kind of separately, in either Minnesota or in Texas, initial conversations with policy-makers and the timing around your legislative initiatives in both of those states?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, let me just say that I've had the opportunity, as have others on the Xcel team, to talk about what we're trying to accomplish. And as I mentioned, it's -- I think there's a lot of excitement. And I think there is -- the devil is always in the d
componenttext: Yes. Well, let me just say that I've had the opportunity, as have others on the Xcel team, to talk about what we're trying to accomplish. And as I mentioned, it's -- I think there's a lot of excitement. And I think there is -- the devil is always in the details, as you know. But I think there's a lot of excitement that this is a way we ought to be going in the state. So that's from a regulatory perspective. We'd like to potentially have legislation that would support that new regulatory framework in Minnesota. So more to come on that, obviously. In Texas, I think we're getting some traction. It's still a little bit early days. They haven't even assigned -- made committees assignments to the key committees that would drive legislation for us. But we haven't seen any major roadblocks at this point.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: At this time, we'll take a question from Jonathan Arnold, Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: At this time, we'll take a question from Jonathan Arnold, Deutsche Bank.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: A quick one on -- you've mentioned exploring ways to avoid a 2016 Minnesota rate case, could you elaborate?
componenttext: A quick one on -- you've mentioned exploring ways to avoid a 2016 Minnesota rate case, could you elaborate?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take a stab at it. I mean, first of all, where there's a will, there's a way. And I think -- as I said, I think there's really a will to -- lets get the 2016 case out of the way and let's focus on this longer-term framework. So how would we
componenttext: Yes, let me take a stab at it. I mean, first of all, where there's a will, there's a way. And I think -- as I said, I think there's really a will to -- lets get the 2016 case out of the way and let's focus on this longer-term framework. So how would we do that mechanically? Well, it starts with using the ALJ recommendations, getting our interim rate proposal adopted close to what we have proposed and then taking a look at our excess depreciation and maybe reshaping that a bit, along with using some of our nuclear depreciation as well. So there's a way, Jonathan. And it would be nice to free up the time so we could spend more time on these other, more longer-term ideas that the community and we have.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It sounds like you might be reasonably well along with having -- getting that done? Is that fair, Ben?
componenttext: It sounds like you might be reasonably well along with having -- getting that done? Is that fair, Ben?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the first step in getting it done was a constructive ALJ settlement. So we've got something to work with now. And then, again, if parties want to do it, I think we've got the pathway forward.
componenttext: Well, I think the first step in getting it done was a constructive ALJ settlement. So we've got something to work with now. And then, again, if parties want to do it, I think we've got the pathway forward.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just another topic, as of the gas rate basing subject, how -- given the change in the commodity price, obviously, it would seem interesting for some of your stakeholders to lock that in. How confident are you that you'll be able to provide
componenttext: Okay. And then just another topic, as of the gas rate basing subject, how -- given the change in the commodity price, obviously, it would seem interesting for some of your stakeholders to lock that in. How confident are you that you'll be able to provide the other side of the deal?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's definitely an economic benefit to moving forward, especially where gas prices are today. But we have to make sure that -- there'll be a lot of concerns. I mean, these aren't -- this won't be an easy lift. But I think the economics are compelling e
componenttext: There's definitely an economic benefit to moving forward, especially where gas prices are today. But we have to make sure that -- there'll be a lot of concerns. I mean, these aren't -- this won't be an easy lift. But I think the economics are compelling enough that I would -- that I have optimism that ultimately, we can get something done. But it's going to take time, Jonathan.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President, Chief Executive Officer; Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition,
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President, Chief Executive Officer; Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition, we have other members of the management team in the room to answer questions.
This morning, we will review our 2015 first quarter results, reaffirm earnings guidance for 2015 and update you on recent business and regulatory developments. Slides that accompany today's call are available on our web page. In addition, we will post a video on our website of Teresa summarizing financial results later this morning.
As a reminder, some of the comments during today's conference call may contain forward-looking information. Significant factors that could cause results to differ from those anticipated are described in our earnings release and our filings with the SEC. 
Today's press release refers to both ongoing and GAAP earnings. 
First quarter 2015 ongoing earnings were $0.46 per share, which excluded charge of $0.16 per share following the decision by the Minnesota commission in the Monticello review. GAAP earnings for the first quarter were $0.03 per share. Management believes ongoing earnings, which removes the impact of charges related to the review provide a more meaningful comparison. As a result, the comments in today's call will focus on first quarter ongoing earnings of $0.46 per share. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Ben.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well thank you, Paul, and good morning. Today, I'm going to provide a business update, review several recent regulatory outcomes, speak to you about our legislative efforts in Minnesota and Texas and discuss our recently increased dividend growth objectiv
componenttext:
Well thank you, Paul, and good morning. Today, I'm going to provide a business update, review several recent regulatory outcomes, speak to you about our legislative efforts in Minnesota and Texas and discuss our recently increased dividend growth objective. Teresa will provide more detail on some of these items. 
We're beginning 2015 with a solid start. While timing and weather differences led to some variability in the quarter, our earnings remain on track and we are reaffirming our 2015 guidance range of $2 to $2.15 per share. In February, we increased our dividend almost 7%. We also raised our annual dividend growth objective to 5% to 7% and established a formal payout of 60% to 70%. These actions reflect our confidence in the company's long-term strategic plan, the strength of our balance sheet and our projected cash flows. 
From an operational perspective, we met key milestones in our transformation business, as we energized the final sections on 2 of our major CapEx 2020 projects, bringing the lines into service on time and on budget. The region will derive meaningful benefits from these valuable assets. 
We're also pleased to be named the #1 win provider in the country for the 11th straight year by AWEA. We're pleased to be included in Forbes Magazine of the 100 most trustworthy companies in America and to be recognized as the best for Vets Employer. 
From a regulatory perspective, we brought 3 major proceedings to a close. In Colorado, the commission approved our 3-year electrical regulatory plan. This constructive multiyear settlement provides rate certainty for our customers and revenue certainty for our company. This represents the second multiyear plan we have implemented in our Colorado electric business, and we believe that this agreement can service a blueprint for our pending natural gas rate case. 
Turning to Minnesota. We continue to believe we acted prudently throughout the construction process at our Monticello nuclear facility. The important takeaway is that our customers and the region will benefit from a safe, reliable and diverse fuel mix, including nuclear, for many years to come. While we disagree with some of the commission's findings, and we will need to review the final order, it does represent resolution of initiative that has been an overhang on the company. 
Finally, in our inaugural, multiyear rate case in Minnesota, we were encouraged that the commission generally agree with the ALJ recommendations in the preceding and the support of the company's position on many other key issues. And while we would have preferred to avoid a 2016 regulatory filing, and we felt we provided a path to do so, we believe the final result was a reasonable outcome. However, we continue to believe there's an opportunity for future improvement in streamlining of the regulatory process. We feel that more specific legislation will facilitate this and provide greater predictability for customers and the company. 
In order to achieve the ambitious state and federal policy initiatives that are quickly approaching, it's important that the company have additional tools at its disposal to meet these evolving requirements. As a result, we've been proactively working with key stakeholders on our multiyear plan regulatory bill currently being considered by the Minnesota Legislature. Some of the key components of this regulatory compact include: expanding to a 5-year multiyear plan; allowing for a formulate recovery of capital investments; recovery of O&M expenses based on our electric industry price index; continuation of interim rates while the plan is on our consideration; and protections in the event of unforeseen developments. 
The proposed multiyear plan legislation is contained in the omnibus house energy bill. The state omnibus energy bill does not include the multiyear plan legislation. The energy bills have passed the floor boat in both the House and the Senate. The bills will now be reconciled in conference committee, and we expect the final bill will include the multiyear plan legislation. Once the committee has reconciled the bill, it will be sent back to the Senate and House for a vote and while the process remains fluid, we are cautiously optimistic regarding its passage. If successful, we will look to incorporate components of the bill as appropriate in our rate filings in the future. 
In Texas, we've worked with various stakeholders on a bill that addresses regulatory lag. The regulatory bill passed out of the house committee earlier this month, and we are waiting for it to be scheduled for a vote on the floor. The proposed legislation provides for the inclusion of posttest year rate base additions and supports the implementation of more timely surcharges. However, industrial customers continue to have concerns with the bill and we are currently working to resolve these issues. We are hopeful that the bill will be passed into law as it is an important step towards reducing regulatory lag and would help to facilitate investment in the growing area. 
Late last year, we discussed our plans to focus on incremental growth opportunities in transmission and natural gas assets. Recently, we've been socializing the concept our rate basing natural gas reserves in Colorado. We are working with stakeholders to see if we can schedule a series of discussions to explore the concept of rate basing natural gas reserves and how to best take advantage of the current low natural gas price for the benefit of customers and the company alike. 
Finally, I wanted to brief you on about an exciting new investment that we're pursuing. Courtney has a 200-megawatt wind power purchase agreement that NSP-Minnesota signed in 2013. For various reasons, the developer has decided to exit the project, providing us an opportunity to pursue ownership of the wind farm and to ensure that our customers will benefit from the addition of cost-effective wind generation. We are seeking regulatory approval in Minnesota and North Dakota to take this project over and eventually place it in rate base. The facility's expected to be in service at the end of 2016 and cost approximately $300 million. The project is not included in our current 5-year capital forecast, and we don't anticipate needing to issue any incremental equity to finance it. 
We've made significant progress in the first 4 months of this year and I look forward to making even more progress in the coming months. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Teresa.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, we reported ongoing earnings for the first quarter of $0.46 per share versus $0.52 per share last year. While the court to some timing differences and adverse weather comparison, the results were in line with our expe
componenttext:
Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, we reported ongoing earnings for the first quarter of $0.46 per share versus $0.52 per share last year. While the court to some timing differences and adverse weather comparison, the results were in line with our expectations. The most significant driver in the quarter was improved electric margin that resulted from new rates. However, the weather comparison versus 2014 was significant, causing a $0.05 per share negative variance. Increased O&M and depreciation, along with a higher effective tax rate, were also notable offsets. 
Now let me provide an update on sales and the economies in our local service territories. Weather normalized electric sales increased 0.5% for the quarter in natural gas sales rose 2.9%. In the first quarter of 2014, we experienced very cold weather. As we all know, the weather normalization process is not in an exact science. And it is possible that our first quarter 2014 weather normalized sales may have been somewhat distorted. With that in mind, we continue to be confident in our 2015 electric weather adjusted sales growth assumptions of 1%. 
Let me provide a little more detail on sales growth by company. Beginning with NSP-Wisconsin, weather adjusted retail sales increased 1.7%, due primarily to growth in the oil, gas and sand mining related businesses. Electric sales at SPS increased 1.9%, driven by growth in both the residential and C&I classes. While we are closely monitoring the impact of oil prices on production activity, the Permian Basin has been resilient. PSCo's electric sales increased 0.04%, which is primarily attributable to the strength in the C&I class due to expansions in the health care and technology services sectors. 
Finally, NSP-Minnesota's electric sales decreased 0.5% as usage declines more than offset new customer additions in both the residential and C&I classes. 
Overall, our service territories remain healthy, particularly relative to the rest of the nation. Consolidated unemployment in our regions is 4.2%, well below the national average of 5.6%. The number of jobs in our regions grew 2.5% during the quarter compared with 2.3% for the nation. 
Focusing on earnings for the quarter. Ongoing electric margin increased to $40 million. Key drivers included: nonfuel riders that increased margin by $34 million, largely reflecting the clean air, clean jobs rider in Colorado, which became effective January 1, 2015; the implementation of final and interim rates increased margin by $23 million; and increased net transmission revenue, which improved margin by $7 million. Offsetting these positive factors was an unfavorable weather comparison year-over-year of $25 million, as well as a few other less significant items. 
It is worth noting that during the first quarter of 2015, we took a conservative approach to revenue recognition. During the quarter, we continue to book revenues at the 2014 interim rate level and did not assume that the Minnesota commission would approve our netting proposal, which would have increased revenues by just over $10 million. If the NPC approves our interim rate netting proposal, we will record revenue in that period at the higher authorized level retroactive to January 1, 2015. 
When thinking about margin comparisons for the remainder of the year, it is important to remember that as we move through the balance of 2014, we recorded increasingly larger potential refunds to customers, ending the year with a rate increase consistent with the ALJ recommendation. Due to these timing factors, we expect an improving margin comparison in Minnesota for the remainder of the year. 
Margins on the natural gas side of our business decreased by $12 million for the quarter. This was primarily due to the negative weather comparison, which more than offset higher rider revenues and retail sales growth. 
O&M expenses increased $26 million in the quarter. The higher level is almost entirely driven by the timing of plant outages. We remain confident that we will achieve our annual O&M growth assumption of 0% to 2%. 
Depreciation expense increased $27 million for the quarter due to capital investment and lower amortization of the excess depreciation reserve in Minnesota. 
Finally, other taxes increased about $12 million, largely driven by higher property taxes in Minnesota and Colorado. 
Next, I'll provide an update on several regulatory proceedings. Additional details are included in our earnings release. During the quarter, as Ben indicated, we made significant progress with our regulatory agenda, resolving 3 key proceedings. 
Beginning with Minnesota and our multiyear rate filing, we were pleased that the commission recognized the strength of the company's arguments and largely accepted the recommendations of the ALJ. Based on our interpretation of that commission's oral deliberation, we estimate a total revenue increase of $168 million, which compares to our revised request of $221 million. The commission approved a 9.72% ROE and equity ratio of 52.5% and a 3-year decoupling pilot. We view this as a reasonable outcome and expect the final written order in May. 
We also concluded final deliberations in our Monticello improvements review. The commission approved a full return of $415 million of the project's $748 million total cost. However, allowed recovery of the investment with no return, on the remaining $333 million. As a result, we recorded a one-time pretax charge of $129 million during the quarter. We estimate that the 2015 ongoing pretax impact of the decision will be approximately $16 million on a total company basis. 
Finally, in February, we were pleased that the Colorado commission approved its settlement in our electric rate case. The final decision reflected an overall revenue increase of $53 million in 2015 and ROE of 9.83% and an equity ratio of 56%. In addition, we have implemented forward-looking riders for our clean air, clean jobs and transmission related spending. The agreement covers 2015 through 2017 and continues the productive multiyear regulatory compact that we've been operating under since 2012. 
In March, the PSCo filed a multiyear natural gas rate case covering 2015 through 2017. We are requesting a 2015 rate increase of about $41 million and subsequent step increases of $8 million in 2016 and $18 million in 2017. The requested ROE is 10.1%  in 2015 and '16, rising to 10.3% in 2017. In addition, we filed for a 5-year extension of our pipeline System Integrity rider that drives revenue increases of $22 million and $21 million in 2016 and '17. 
We filed a gas case with principles generally consistent with the recently settled electric case, which we hope will provide the framework for our first multiyear natural gas rate plan in Colorado. 
In our Texas rate case, the schedule has been have been abated for 30 days in order to allow for settlement discussions. However, we haven't been successful in reaching a settlement, therefore, the procedure's schedule to process the case was established on Monday. Regardless, the parties have agreed rates will be effective in mid-June. 
Finally, in South Dakota, interim rates of about $16 million went into effect on January 1. We currently are in settlement in negotiations with parties and expect final rates to be effective midyear. 
This morning, we are reaffirming our 2015 ongoing earnings guidance range of $2 to $2.15 per share. Our guidance range is based on several key assumptions as described in our earnings release, including constructive outcomes in our regulatory proceedings. Please note that some of the assumptions have changed. For more information, please see our earnings release. 
With that, I will wrap up my comments. We are pleased to be making progress with our regulatory agenda. We have gained substantial clarity in recent months and are cautiously optimistic regarding the potential success of our legislative initiatives. We are reaffirming our 2015 ongoing earnings guidance of $2 to $2.15 per share. We are excited about the Courtney windfarm investment opportunity. We continue to expect 2015 O&M to be flat to up to 2%. We are well positioned to deliver an attractive long-term value to our shareholders by growing earnings 4% to 6% annually. 
And finally, we are pleased to raise our dividend growth objective to 5% to 7%. 
So operator, we'll now take questions.

And perhaps a more relevant question here, if you don't get the litigation by the end of May or what have you, as you think about the '16 case, is there any potential to have a multiyear stay out under a variety -- any variety of its scenario that would exclude legislation?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, Julien, we had a path to stay out of '16, but it was going to be based upon how we handle certain depreciation reserves. And so when that opportunity was not taken, it put us in the position, as you know, that we are going to file the 2016 case. Now
componenttext: Well, Julien, we had a path to stay out of '16, but it was going to be based upon how we handle certain depreciation reserves. And so when that opportunity was not taken, it put us in the position, as you know, that we are going to file the 2016 case. Now we have mitigation tools still available to us. If the legislation passed, we might have more tools, longer timeframes that we could do. But even if the legislation doesn't pass, we are going to file a multiyear plan in 2016. And when we look at our spend profile and our recovery needs, I think the longer the plan is, the more modulation in mitigation we can use for the benefit of our customers and for clarity for us. So I think we've got a pretty solid path to start to close out regulatory lag, it's been really pronounced in Minnesota. Legislation will help but the traditional way to file a rate case, although laborious, also works.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015

componenttext: And perhaps, and I know this is very tough to ask, but how do you think about collapsing the rate lag just organically given smaller rate case prospectively in '15? I mean, how much of the improvement here is simply, again, just another filing with a more modest ask and having some of mitigation tools versus having the legislation in hand and leveraging some of those tools that enables you? I mean, what kind of delta are we talking about? And I know that's putting a lot.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Pretty hard to quantify that, I would say. I mean, let me just say that the majority of the ask in '16, whether we use legislative initiatives or what we have available to use now is going to be capital driven. So Julien, I think that always helps. Capita
componenttext: Pretty hard to quantify that, I would say. I mean, let me just say that the majority of the ask in '16, whether we use legislative initiatives or what we have available to use now is going to be capital driven. So Julien, I think that always helps. Capital's always less controversial than O&M. The advantage, though, of a longer timeframe is that we have more opportunities to sculpt the capital to -- and the mitigation tools to take advantage of the fact that the pace of investment does start to slow down. And again, what we've talked about before is that, we really need to have longer time frames where we're not in front of the regulator in a litigious kind of proceeding trying to get rate relief because there's a lot of policy discussions that we want to have and frankly, I think our commission wants to have with us. But we can't do that right now. So that was the disappointment, really, of having to file a '16 case. As there's a lot going on and it kind of makes it hard to have those dialogues. But the dialogues will happen. So did I answer your question, hopefully?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: It really hasn't had much of an impact at all, place from an economic standpoint, we understand that there's more supply chain initiatives from developers squeezing out more cost. But the other thing, and I think that's very important to recognize, is tha
componenttext: It really hasn't had much of an impact at all, place from an economic standpoint, we understand that there's more supply chain initiatives from developers squeezing out more cost. But the other thing, and I think that's very important to recognize, is that we had a tremendous backlog. So you've got well -- we've got the majority of the wells but still don't -- or still running on very expensive diesel and things like that. So there's a lot of backlog, it gives us time to catch up. Ultimately, I think prices will rebound a bit. But I think we're in pretty good shape there. And the other thing that's happening is in that area of the country, there's other economic activity as well. So still going pretty strong and the sales growth expectations down in that region are pretty strong. And we think we'll continue to be so.

componenttext: I'm wondering, as you went through the 2014, '15 rate stuff in Minnesota, were there lesson learned through that whole process that you expect to embed in the 2016 case? Anything that you might have asked for before that you want to ask for now? Any adjustments that you'll make absent of the legislation in that whole side of it.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, it reaffirm to us that we need to change the regulatory process. That's -- I mean, that's why we're seeking a legislation. It doesn't allow us to have the dialogues, Travis, that we mentioned. We need -- there's a new world. Our policymakers want
componenttext: I guess, it reaffirm to us that we need to change the regulatory process. That's -- I mean, that's why we're seeking a legislation. It doesn't allow us to have the dialogues, Travis, that we mentioned. We need -- there's a new world. Our policymakers want us to do more and frankly, we are doing more. We filed, and I think a very transformational resource plan at the end of last year. We're going to move forward and be very aggressive on renewables. We want to make sure we do that with efficiency in mind, using large scale renewables. It's tough to do that, as I've mentioned, in the rate case. I guess, specifically, we need to -- we probably self-mitigated a little bit as we filed that rate case, recognizing that was a big ask. And that puts -- those things we didn't ask for will just resurface in '16 and we'll ask for what we need and as I've mentioned, it's capital based. These are investments that I think everybody wants us to make. So we've got to update the regulatory compact in keeping with the times. And I think that's what the E 21 initiative was about and we're proposing how we implement that in Minnesota.

componenttext: We don't, as you know, we haven't assumed -- what we have in our transmission CapEx is kind of, it's state regulated and it's identified. It's not pie in the sky. So we don't have competitive transmission. But there are -- but opportunities are fewer, as you know, than what I think people were talking about a year ago. But there are some opportunities. And we're looking at a relatively small opportunity in MISO, potentially some smaller opportunities in SPP, which I think, will give us a chance to understand how competitive bidding will work. Relatively small right now. I think as the EPA rules get clarified in both SPP and MISO refine their projects, or refind the needs, we'll have more opportunities to bid competitively.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to go back again to this Minnesota legislation. I mean, we've been following it and so here, a couple of concerns that we have. I mean, first of all, it seems that the legislature is split in Minnesota. And so why do you feel convinced or hope
componenttext: I just want to go back again to this Minnesota legislation. I mean, we've been following it and so here, a couple of concerns that we have. I mean, first of all, it seems that the legislature is split in Minnesota. And so why do you feel convinced or hopeful that both House and the Senate can agree on the version of a bill that will actually those multiyear rate cases? And more importantly, so we have this issue in Colorado earlier that regulators didn't necessarily think that this -- that the new law is really binding, it's more of a suggestion. So how likely is it that we do get a bill and then that the regulators in Minnesota think that it's still an option for them to pursue or not? And then, we may end up at yet another rate case.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, couple of questions that you asked. I mean, first of all, as we all know, making in the political process can be kind of messy. And that's what we're in. And -- but what we're being told and what we understand is while there's controversy between th
componenttext: Well, couple of questions that you asked. I mean, first of all, as we all know, making in the political process can be kind of messy. And that's what we're in. And -- but what we're being told and what we understand is while there's controversy between the House and Senate bill, and that's the difference between Republican versus DFL controlled and they're different interest, the multiyear plan provisions really aren't controversial. So when this thing goes to conference committee, we think it's a very good possibility that the provisions of the multiyear plan remain. While you can only be cautiously optimistic because it is a political process and if there were things in the final bill that was passed by both House and Senate that were unappealing to the Governor, you always have a risk of veto. So that's the reality there. In terms of whether if it will be viewed by the commission as an option versus a mandate, I think one, you'd have to look and see how the legislation is finalized. But I also believe that the commission is frustrated with how the process works in Minnesota too. So I think you kind of saw that as the commission was thinking about the opportunity that we said to stay out of 2016. And I'm not sure that they felt they were -- it was quite ready. And so with legislation, even if it's an option versus a mandate, I think they feel much more comfortable with that. Chris, we have Chris here. I don't know if, Chris, you want to add to that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In additi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Xcel Energy's 2015 First Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. Joining me today are Ben Fowke, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Teresa Madden, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. In addition, we have other members of the management team in the room to answer questions.
This morning, we will review our 2015 first quarter results, reaffirm earnings guidance for 2015 and update you on recent business and regulatory developments. Slides that accompany today's call are available on our web page. In addition, we will post a video on our website of Teresa summarizing financial results later this morning.
As a reminder, some of the comments during today's conference call may contain forward-looking information. Significant factors that could cause results to differ from those anticipated are described in our earnings release and our filings with the SEC. Today's press release refers to both ongoing and GAAP earnings. 
First quarter 2015 ongoing earnings were $0.46 per share, which excluded charge of $0.16 per share following the decision by the Minnesota Commission in the Monticello Prudence Review. GAAP earnings for the first quarter were $0.30 per share. Management believes ongoing earnings, which removes the impact of charges related to the prudence review provide a more meaningful comparison. As a result, the comments in today's call will focus on first quarter ongoing earnings of $0.46 per share. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Ben.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well thank you, Paul, and good morning. Today, I'm going to provide a business update, review several recent regulatory outcomes, speak to you about our legislative efforts in Minnesota and Texas and discuss our recently increased dividend growth objectiv
componenttext:
Well thank you, Paul, and good morning. Today, I'm going to provide a business update, review several recent regulatory outcomes, speak to you about our legislative efforts in Minnesota and Texas and discuss our recently increased dividend growth objective. Teresa will provide more detail on some of these items. 
We're beginning 2005 (sic)  with a solid start. While timing and weather differences led to some variability in the quarter, our earnings remain on track, and we are reaffirming our 2015 guidance range of $2 to $2.15 per share. In February, we increased our dividend almost 7%. We also raised our annual dividend growth objective to 5% to 7% and established a formal payout target of 60% to 70%. These actions reflect our confidence in the company's long-term strategic plan, the strength of our balance sheet and our projected cash flows. 
From an operational perspective, we met key milestones in our transmission business, as we energized the final sections on 2 of our major CapEx 2020 projects, bringing the lines into service on time and on budget. The region will derive meaningful benefits from these valuable assets. 
We're also pleased to be named the #1 wind provider in the country for the 11th straight year by AWEA. We're pleased to be included in Forbes Magazine of the 100 Most Trustworthy Companies in America and to be recognized as the Best for Vets Employer. 
From a regulatory perspective, we brought 3 major proceedings to a close. In Colorado, the commission approved our 3-year electric regulatory plan. This constructive multiyear settlement provides rate certainty for our customers and revenue certainty for the company. This represents the second multiyear plan we have implemented in our Colorado electric business, and we believe that this agreement can service a blueprint for our pending natural gas rate case. 
Turning to Minnesota. We continue to believe we acted prudently throughout the construction process at our Monticello nuclear facility. The important takeaway is that our customers and the region will benefit from a safe, reliable and diverse fuel mix, including nuclear, for many years to come. While we disagree with some of the commission's findings, and we will need to review the final order, it does represent resolution of an issue that has been an overhang on the company. 
Finally, in our inaugural, multiyear rate case in Minnesota, we were encouraged that the commission generally agree with the ALJ recommendations in the proceeding and supported the company's position on many other key issues. And while we would have preferred to avoid a 2016 regulatory filing, and we felt we provided a path to do so, we believe the final result was a reasonable outcome. However, we continue to believe there's an opportunity for future improvement in streamlining the regulatory process. We feel that more specific legislation will facilitate this and provide greater predictability for customers and the company. 
In order to achieve the ambitious state and federal policy initiatives that are quickly approaching, it's important that the company have additional tools at its disposal to meet these evolving requirements. As a result, we've been proactively working with key stakeholders on our multiyear plan regulatory bill currently being considered by the Minnesota Legislature. Some of the key components of this regulatory compact include: expanding to a 5-year multiyear plan, allowing for formulaic recovery of capital investments, recovery of O&M expenses based on our electric industry price index, continuation of interim rates while the plan is under consideration and protections in the event of unforeseen developments. 
The proposed multiyear plan legislation is contained in the Omnibus House Energy Bill. The state Omnibus Energy Bill does not include the multiyear plan legislation. The energy bills have passed the floor vote in both the House and the Senate. The bills will now be reconciled in conference committee, and we expect the final bill will include the multiyear plan legislation. Once the committee has reconciled the bill, it will be sent back to the Senate and House for a vote, and while the process remains fluid, we are cautiously optimistic regarding its passage. If successful, we will look to incorporate components of the bill as appropriate in our rate filings in the future. 
In Texas, we've worked with various stakeholders on a bill that addresses regulatory lag. The regulatory bill passed out of the house committee earlier this month, and we are waiting for it to be scheduled for a vote on the floor. The proposed legislation provides for the inclusion of post-test year rate base additions and supports the implementation of more timely surcharges. However, industrial customers continue to have concerns with the bill, and we are currently working to resolve these issues. We are hopeful that the bill will be passed into law, as it is an important step towards reducing regulatory lag and would help to facilitate investment in the growing areas. 
Late last year, we discussed our plans to focus on incremental growth opportunities in transmission and natural gas assets. Recently, we've been socializing the concept of rate-basing natural gas reserves in Colorado. We are working with stakeholders to see if we can schedule a series of discussions to explore the concept of rate-basing natural gas reserves and how to best take advantage of the current low natural gas price for the benefit of customers and the company alike. 
Finally, I wanted to brief you on about an exciting new investment that we're pursuing. Courtenay has a 200-megawatt wind power purchase agreement that NSP-Minnesota signed in 2013. For various reasons, the developer has decided to exit the project, providing us an opportunity to pursue ownership of the wind farm and to ensure that our customers will benefit from the addition of cost-effective wind generation. We are seeking regulatory approval in Minnesota and North Dakota to take this project over and eventually placing in rate base. The facility is expected to be in service at the end of 2016 and costs approximately $300 million. The project is not included in our current 5-year capital forecast, and we don't anticipate needing to issue any incremental equity to finance it. We've made significant progress in the first 4 months of this year, and I look forward to making even more progress in the coming months. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Teresa.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 30, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, we reported ongoing earnings for the first quarter of $0.46 per share versus $0.52 per share last year. While the quarter was subject to some timing differences and an adverse weather comparison, the results were in l
componenttext:
Thanks, Ben, and good morning. Today, we reported ongoing earnings for the first quarter of $0.46 per share versus $0.52 per share last year. While the quarter was subject to some timing differences and an adverse weather comparison, the results were in line with our expectations. The most significant driver in the quarter was improved electric margin that resulted from new rates. However, the weather comparison versus 2014 was significant, causing a $0.05 per share negative variance. Increased O&M and depreciation, along with a higher effective tax rate, were also notable offsets. 
Now let me provide an update on sales and the economies in our local service territories. Weather-normalized electric sales increased 0.5% for the quarter, and natural gas sales rose 2.9%. In the first quarter of 2014, we experienced very cold weather. As we all know, the weather normalization process is not an exact science, and it is possible that our first quarter 2014 weather-normalized sales may have been somewhat distorted. With that in mind, we continue to be confident in our 2015 electric weather adjusted sales growth assumption of 1%. 
Let me provide a little more detail on sales growth by company. Beginning with NSP-Wisconsin, weather-adjusted retail sales increased 1.7% due primarily to growth in the oil, gas and sand mining-related businesses. Electric sales at SPS increased 1.9%, driven by growth in both the residential and C&I classes. While we are closely monitoring the impact of oil prices on production activity, the Permian Basin has been resilient. PSCo's electric sales increased 0.4%, which was primarily attributable to strengths in the C&I class due to expansions in the health care and technology services sectors. Finally, NSP-Minnesota's electric sales decreased 0.5% as usage declines more than offset new customer additions in both the residential and C&I classes. 
Overall, our service territories remain healthy, particularly relative to the rest of the nation. Consolidated unemployment in our regions is 4.2%, well below the national average of 5.6%. The number of jobs in our regions grew 2.5% during the quarter compared with 2.3% for the nation. 
Focusing on earnings for the quarter. Ongoing electric margin increased to $40 million. Key drivers included: nonfuel riders that increased margin by $34 million, largely reflecting the Clean Air-Clean Jobs rider in Colorado, which became effective January 1, 2015; the implementation of final and interim rates increased margin by $23 million; and increased net transmission revenue, which improved margin by $7 million. Offsetting these positive factors was an unfavorable weather comparison year-over-year of $25 million as well as a few other less significant items. 
It is worth noting that during the first quarter of 2015, we took a conservative approach to revenue recognition. During the quarter, we continue to book revenues at the 2014 interim-rate level and did not assume that the Minnesota Commission would approve our netting proposal, which would have increased revenues by just over $10 million. If the MPUC approves our interim-rate netting proposal, we will record revenue in that period at the higher authorized level retroactive to January 1, 2015. 
When thinking about margin comparisons for the remainder of the year, it is important to remember that as we move through the balance of 2014, we recorded increasingly larger potential refunds to customers, ending the year with a rate increase consistent with the ALJ recommendation. Due to these timing factors, we expect an improving margin comparison in Minnesota for the remainder of the year. 
Margins on the natural gas side of our business decreased by $12 million for the quarter. This was primarily due to the negative weather comparison, which more than offset higher rider revenue and retail sales growth. 
O&M expenses increased $26 million in the quarter. The higher level is almost entirely driven by the timing of planned outages. We remain confident that we will achieve our annual O&M growth assumption of 0% to 2%. 
Depreciation expense increased $27 million for the quarter due to capital investment and lower amortization of the excess depreciation reserve in Minnesota. Finally, other taxes increased about $12 million, largely driven by higher property taxes in Minnesota and Colorado. 
Next, I'll provide an update on several regulatory proceedings. Additional details are included in our earnings release. During the quarter, as Ben indicated, we made significant progress with our regulatory agenda, resolving 3 key proceedings, beginning with Minnesota and our multiyear rate filing. We were pleased that the commission recognized the strength of the company's arguments and largely accepted the recommendations of the ALJ. Based on our interpretation of the commission's oral deliberations, we estimate a total revenue increase of $168 million, which compares to our revised request of $221 million. The commission approved a 9.72% ROE, an equity ratio of 52.5% and a 3-year decoupling pilot. We view this as a reasonable outcome and expect the final written order in May. 
We also concluded final deliberations in our Monticello Prudence Review. The commission approved a full return on $415 million of the project's $748 million total cost, however, allowed recovery of the investment with no return on the remaining $333 million. As a result, we recorded a onetime pretax charge of $129 million during the quarter. We estimate that the 2015 ongoing pretax impact of the decision will be approximately $16 million on a total company basis. 
Finally, in February, we were pleased that the Colorado commission approved the settlement in our electric rate case. The final decision reflected an overall revenue increase of $53 million in 2015, an ROE of 9.83% and an equity ratio of 56%. In addition, we have implemented forward-looking riders for our Clean Air-Clean Jobs and transmission-related spending. The agreement covers 2015 through 2017 and continues the productive multiyear regulatory compact that we've been operating under since 2012. 
In March, the PSCo filed a multiyear natural gas rate case covering 2015 through 2017. We are requesting a 2015 rate increase of about $41 million and subsequent step increases of $8 million in 2016 and $18 million in 2017. The requested ROE is 10.1%  in 2015 and '16, rising to 10.3% in 2017. In addition, we filed for a 5-year extension of our Pipeline System Integrity rider that drives revenue increases of $22 million and $21 million in 2016 and '17. We filed a gas case with principles generally consistent with the recently settled electric case, which we hope will provide the framework for our first multiyear natural gas rate plan in Colorado. 
In our Texas rate case, the schedule has been -- had been abated for 30 days in order to allow for settlement discussions. However, we haven't been successful in reaching a settlement. Therefore, the procedure's schedule to process the case was established on Monday. Regardless, the parties have agreed rates will be effective in mid-June. 
Finally, in South Dakota, interim rates of about $16 million went into effect on January 1. We currently are in settlement negotiations with parties and expect final rates to be effective midyear. 
This morning, we are reaffirming our 2015 ongoing earnings guidance range of $2 to $2.15 per share. Our guidance range is based on several key assumptions as described in our earnings release, including constructive outcomes in our regulatory proceedings. Please note that some of the assumptions have changed. For more information, please see our earnings release. 
With that, I will wrap up my comments. We are pleased to be making progress with our regulatory agenda. We have gained substantial clarity in recent months and are cautiously optimistic regarding the potential success of our legislative initiatives. We are reaffirming our 2015 ongoing earnings guidance of $2 to $2.15 per share. We are excited about the Courtenay Wind Farm investment opportunity. We continue to expect 2015 O&M to be flat to up to 2%. We are well positioned to deliver an attractive long-term value to our shareholders by growing earnings 4% to 6% annually. And finally, we are pleased to raise our dividend growth objective to 5% to 7%. 
So operator, we'll now take questions.
