headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: The -- a couple of things. You guys put a pretty compelling story up for the multiyear plan, and what have you, in Minnesota. But I'm just wondering if it were not to happen, are there other levers that you guys are contemplating for perhaps closing the R
componenttext: The -- a couple of things. You guys put a pretty compelling story up for the multiyear plan, and what have you, in Minnesota. But I'm just wondering if it were not to happen, are there other levers that you guys are contemplating for perhaps closing the ROE lag or potential ROE lag going forward?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I mean, we would -- we're obviously going to do what -- everything we can to achieve our earnings goals. So we'd have to see. I mean, we're -- I'm pretty confident that we're going to be able to get a multiyear plan in place. I'd rather it be 5, but it co
componenttext: I mean, we would -- we're obviously going to do what -- everything we can to achieve our earnings goals. So we'd have to see. I mean, we're -- I'm pretty confident that we're going to be able to get a multiyear plan in place. I'd rather it be 5, but it could be 3. And I think there's a lot of openness to that. So I think we're getting into really hypothetical situations. We'd have to react to whatever the commission, as we always do, gave us. And the point is, we're going to -- we would have to be even -- probably more disciplined on the cost side. But I -- you start to get -- you can achieve earnings goals, but at some point, I think they'd cut into some of your other objectives with building out the infrastructure, modernizing and getting customers better options, achieving environmental excellence, all those things that are kind of the hallmark of Xcel Energy. So I don't think that's a bridge we're going to have to cross, Paul.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would agree with you. I mean, frankly, we've already completed 1 multiyear plan. So we have the precedent behind us.
componenttext: I would agree with you. I mean, frankly, we've already completed 1 multiyear plan. So we have the precedent behind us.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, you're right, Teresa. We did [ph] a real step-back.
componenttext: Yes, you're right, Teresa. We did [ph] a real step-back.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And we have the new legislation. So I mean, that seems like minimal risk that we would not be able to complete a multiyear. It's just how many years.
componenttext: Yes. And we have the new legislation. So I mean, that seems like minimal risk that we would not be able to complete a multiyear. It's just how many years.

componenttext: Okay. Then the second question -- and I apologize, I just didn't get this completely. You guys mentioned, I think, transferring assets -- transmission assets from SPS to a transco. Could you elaborate a little bit more on that in terms of the size of the assets and what have you?

componenttext: That sounds pretty small. I mean, so the purpose of this -- I mean, obviously, you might want to prefer a transco. But you said, it's a seeded, so therefore, you could expand on it, you think, in a more effective way? Or grow it or something in a more effective way than where it currently is?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay. So I guess, let's stay tuned on that. And then on winds versus fossil -- and you made sort of an intriguing concept, I think, without the tax, but you think it'll be competitive. Could you just elaborate a little bit more on that? Or if you could just quantify that slightly to me in terms of what you -- how competitive you're seeing that in terms of fossil?

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, let's start what we have today, okay? And I'll stick with wind, which does enjoy the production tax credit, which is worth about $22 a megawatt hour. So with that credit in mind, we're seeing wind deals that have come to us across all of our
componenttext: Well, I mean, let's start what we have today, okay? And I'll stick with wind, which does enjoy the production tax credit, which is worth about $22 a megawatt hour. So with that credit in mind, we're seeing wind deals that have come to us across all of our regions in the mid-20s a megawatt hour, levelized, 20 years. Now compare that, Paul, to what we could go out today and buy a strip of natural gas, future contracts for. I mean, even in this low gas-priced environment, if you took those gas reserves, took it -- times it by the applicable heat rate, I think you'd find $25 a megawatt hour for wind to be on parity, if not, in the money. So essentially, what we're doing when we're buying wind is hedging natural gas volatility. Now obviously, if you take away $22 from the equation, you're not looking at $25, you're looking at $47. It's a little bit out of the money. Of course, natural gas prices are at historic lows. And then I would say that -- and this applies to solar as well, is that they continue these technologies at large scale to become more and more efficient. And so I don't think their pricing's going to go up. I think if wind, if anything, will stay flat. But I mean, we've seen -- gosh, in just 5 years, we've seen capacity factors go from the mid-30s to now the low 50s. So they've seen steady improvements. We all know the story with solar. So I am optimistic about it.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. I mean -- and I guess we're just looking at it pure megawatt hour. We're not talking about the benefit of a dispatch or anything like that. We're -- you're just saying if you look at it from a pure megawatt hour perspective and with technology, you'
componenttext: Okay. I mean -- and I guess we're just looking at it pure megawatt hour. We're not talking about the benefit of a dispatch or anything like that. We're -- you're just saying if you look at it from a pure megawatt hour perspective and with technology, you're thinking that you could get somewhere close to that.

headline: Xcel Energy Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. But then, Paul, that's a really good question. And I'd be happy to talk to you more about it because I was just looking at that -- I used wind as an example because I think it's easy to get your arms around. Wind, today, you still have -- you still b
componenttext: Yes. But then, Paul, that's a really good question. And I'd be happy to talk to you more about it because I was just looking at that -- I used wind as an example because I think it's easy to get your arms around. Wind, today, you still have -- you still build the gas plant, right? Okay. But whether you fire up that gas plant with natural gas or you idle it and have it ready to go, but you displace that natural gas with wind is the equation I was talking to you about. It gets a little more complicated when we talk about solar. And the way I look at it, briefly, is it probably -- the capacity value that you bake into that is the difference between a combined cycle plant and a combustion turbine plant, roughly. I mean, there's -- it gets a little more complicated, and we probably can take it offline, but it's pretty exciting economics. And then, you get the ancillary costs as you get more on the system. It's one of the reasons why we're studying more and more what batteries can do for us. It's not like batteries are in the money for us today, but neither was solar 10 years ago. And so we want to be ready for when those -- when the technology moves into the value part of our sweet spot.
